In effect, the purpose of this legislation is to enshrine into legislation a permanent commitment, or as close to permanent as we can get, to tying governments to the future funding of soil conservation. Given the enormity of the problem that faces Australia in terms of soil conservation, I for one applaud that initiative.

During this debate many speakers have dwelt and elaborated on the seriousness of the problems of soil conservation in Australia. There is a natural limitation of Australia's land resources. Australia simply does not have a lot of highly stable or productive land. We have a fragile soil base which, on average, has a relatively low productivity. Those basic limitations of our resources are exacerbated by the often harsh and certainly highly variable climatic conditions that exist throughout Australia. All those factors-that natural predisposition, the harsh climatic conditions-predispose Australia's soil to a number of elements, such as wind and water erosion, salination and the depletion of chemical and physical fertility. If we add to that predisposition a history of what could be described as poor, or at least indifferent, agricultural land management over a century or more and certainly a history of overclearing, overgrazing and often overirrigation, we have an outcome that is very severe and rapidly worsening. This needs the attention of all people throughout Australia and certainly the attention of governments.

There are a number of consequences of that worsening degradation of the soil. The costs to the nation are enormous in terms of lost productivity and economic hardship. They also induce permanent changes to the Australian environment. It is worthy of note that the Commonwealth and State Governments collaborative soil study, which was undertaken between 1975 and 1977, found that more than half of Australian land in use for agricultural or pastoral activities required treatment for land degradation if productivity was to be maintained. At that time, in June 1975, it was estimated by that collaborative study that necessary treatment works to control land degradation throughout the affected areas was of the order of $700m. That was back in 1975. If we apply some increases in prices and costs that have occurred since, we see that as a result of that study the cost of repairing land degradation in Australia in current money values is $1.6 billion. That is a staggering figure. But it is even more staggering when we realise that that estimate deals only with the treatment and control of land degradation. The figure does not include the untold billions of dollars which have no doubt already been lost to the nation because of soil degradation and the consequent reduced agricultural productivity.

While there has been general support for this legislation from the Opposition parties, a number of speakers have been quick to attempt to criticise the Bill. There is no doubt in my mind that the enormous magnitude of the problem, and the threat which it represents to Australia's land resource base, demands active and positive consideration by the Commonwealth Government. Since we took government in March l983, we have demonstrated an active and determined concern to tackle land degradation. The national soil conservation program and the Bill now before the House which will strengthen previous legislation are tangible evidence of the priority that our Government has given to soil conservation. I have referred to the number of Opposition speakers and I think it should be stressed that their own policies in these areas left a great deal to be desired. Our Government has introduced this program and we have been able to contribute limited budgetary commitments of the order of $4m. But it must be emphasised that the Opposition when in government completely turned its back on the issue of soil conservation around Australia. In particular, the National Party of Australia is on record in a number of forums as saying that the Commonwealth has no role or responsibility in overall land management or soil conservation. Members of that Party have argued that that is the responsibility of the States or the individual land owners. The States have a responsibility but it must be a shared responsibility with the Commonwealth because land conservation is not a matter which stops within State boundaries; it traverses State boundaries and, therefore, it is genuinely a national problem. In relation to the claim that it is an individual or private responsibility, I would say that many farmers know and understand the value of their land and their resource base. But in terms of profitability, many farmers are squeezed and are often forced to overgraze or overstock their properties. They overproduce and in a competitive sense they are often stretched to find adequate or available resources to reduce the pressure on their own pastures and to put funds back into soil reclamation and conservation. Therefore, there needs to be a joint co-ordinated approach, a partnership approach to soil conservation throughout Australia. That is what this Government has attempted and is doing. We have put money, legislation and resources into this national program. It is a joint program and it works in conjunction with the States and individual land owners. It is a successful program.

In that respect I wish to mention the local project funded under the national soil conservation scheme which is in my electorate of Bendigo. I have had the pleasure of visiting that project on two occasions and have spent some hours assessing in a detailed way the value of the program. It is a soil salinity treatment and soil conservation project and it is based on the small catchment area philosophy. The project is located on private farms at Burke's Flat between Wedderburn and St Arnaud and it is the product of co-operation between the Commonwealth, the State and individual land owners. Over a two-year period-including work which is scheduled for the autumn months-more than $50,000 has been committed by the Federal Government to fencing, tree planting, pasture establishment, deep drilling and monitoring of bore and rainfall levels. I have visited the project twice and I have spoken to the farmers and the soil conservation officers responsible for it. The farmers involved have put in a great deal of time, effort and money, giving labour, fencing materials and seed. They have also given considerable strategic and planning input to the development of the project. I certainly commend all those local farmers and local officers of the Victorian Soil Conservation Authority on the energy and commitment that they have put into the project. It is already starting to show results in an area of my electorate which is, tragically, the site of enormous dry land salting or salinity.

I have mentioned the partnership approach which I think is crucial to any concerted attempt that we make throughout Australia to address this massive problem of soil conservation. It is not only a problem of preserving a future resource. It is a major environmental problem for all Australians. I believe it ought to be the subject of much greater publicity, interest, knowledge and action by the majority of Australians who are concerned about environmental issues but who perhaps on occasion tend to be diverted to those more glamorous areas of environmental concern. This is a major concern in the environmental sense and if not addressed-and we need increasing resources to do so-it will become an almost insoluble problem in the future.

In conclusion, the establishment of this program provides a degree of certainty to the forward planning of local soil conservation projects such as the one I have described at Burke's Flat. This Bill formalises the strength of the Government's commitment to soil conservation and it brings a previously absent longer term stability to the funding base of soil conservation work in Australia. I think it is a very timely piece of legislation. It is a very forward looking piece of legislation which is of vital importance to the well-being of this country. I commend the Bill to the House, and I hope that in future Budget appropriations the Commonwealth is able to continue to increase its commitment on an ongoing basis. I note that the Victorian Government recently contributed $32m of funding for salinity control over a four-year program. That is a great initiative by the Cain Government. Again it is putting something into action where previously only words existed. In co-operation with the Victorian Government and farmers throughout Australia, I am sure that this legislation will be effective in redressing this massive problem that confronts us all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to speak in support of the Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Bill 1985, which recognises the importance of the maintenance of Australia's most valuable physical resource, although I have certain reservations about it which will be outlined as I go through my speech. Soil is our most valuable physical resource because it is an integral part of the ecology of any district environment. I believe it is important for people to realise that it is not only the Government or fringe environmental groups which have a good understanding of environmental issues. There are many people within the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia who have a very basic understanding and a very strong feeling for these issues. They have worked the land for generations and they understand from the grassroots level what it really means to conserve the soil. They know at first hand the problems that are involved. We, as a Party, understand that the soil is very important for plants and their growth. The soil provides us with many of the minerals for both our plants and our animals. It is vital for holding water so that the water resources can be used in the photosynthetic process, which in turn is the basis of food for humans and all other forms of animal life. It provides resource materials for both humans and animals. That is its importance in a biological sense.

SPEECH.PARA: Soil is also important in an economic sense. Approximately 40 per cent of our exports are directly dependent on the existence of a good soil structure, fertility and texture. It is very important to realise that our nation depends so much on this resource. The Bill makes financial provision for projects initiated not only by government bodies but also by individuals and non-government organisations. I trust that this will be well advertised so that not only government departments but also individuals who have a real interest in maintaining our soil will gain from it. This legislation will be of particular interest to the farmers and others in the rural community who for over 150 years have been dependent on the productivity of our soils. Many in this House will be aware of the pressures that heavy stocking, seasonal variations, floods, fires and frequent cultivation place on maintaining the soil structure. Two-thirds of the land area of Australia is used for agricultural and pastoral activities, and consequently this Bill should encourage farmers and pastoralists to appreciate that governments are concerned about the long term maintenance of soil, even if only in a small way. As one must recognise, the funds that are needed to encourage the research, maintenance and revitalisation of the soils around Australia are but a drop in the ocean.

Of course, the conservation of soil has always been a primary objective of the people who own land. It had to be because so many were dependent on it for their living. Today people in some circles give the impression that they are the only ones concerned about the environment. I refer to the greenies and the various environmental groups. They also tend to think they are the first. Many pastoral and agricultural practices of farming people have been specifically designed to maintain soils. Although this Bill encourages people to keep up the good work, I hope the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee will not become just another part of the bureaucracy that consumes part of our wealth but that it will contribute significantly to ensuring that agricultural production is maintained and improved in the future. That does concern me because there are various illustrations of where government structures have been set up and so much money has been used in their administration that very little filters through to the real place of need.

If this Bill raises the hope and belief that government bodies are more able to manage wisely the soil and environmental resources than are 180,000 rural producers in Australia, let me remind people that it was governments which set up the Ord River scheme, which has been beset with major environmental problems from its inception. The Murray Valley irrigation area, which is now beset with salinity problems-we have heard so much about it in this debate-was also a government project. This teaches us that, even though we may have the best intentions in the world to achieve laudable and highly commendable goals in the area of soil conservation, our knowledge is always limited, particularly when viewed in hindsight. We might have the best will in the world to go ahead with soil conservation, but when we look back in 60 years time we will probably say that we actually went about it in the wrong way. Nevertheless, I believe we have to go ahead and do what we can.

According to L. E. Woods in the publication Land Degradation in Australia, there are four main categories of land use that are pertinent to land degradation. They are: Arid grazing, non-arid grazing, extensive cropping and intensive cropping. When we have a look at some of the figures we notice that intensive cropping involves only 16,000 square kilometres. However, I think it is very important that we recognise the significance of that area of land because, in terms of economic importance to this nation, it probably produces equally with the other areas mentioned and therefore deserves the same sort of consideration under the soil conservation measures.

At first glance one would think that this Bill was directed towards preventing soil erosion mainly by wind and moving water, and many speakers have alluded to that. These are the main forms of erosion with which most people are familiar and they occur mainly in the non-arid and extensive cropping areas. However, this is not the case. I would like to highlight some of those areas requiring conservation that do not yet appear to have much prominence in literature and in the public's mind. One fears that, like the increasing salinity problem in certain areas of Australia, it will not receive adequate attention until it is too late and we have to spend millions of dollars to get the soil back to its correct texture. I refer honourable members to the structural breakdown occurring in some of our intensive cropping areas. Many of those areas of Australia are subject to regular and frequent cultivation with the consequence that the texture of the soils is gradually broken down to a point where they become non-porous and very difficult to work. This occurs due to the frequent use of particular types of implements, such as rotary hoes and discs, that tend to make the particles smaller and smaller until water will not pass between the particles and thus a clay base develops in the soils. This is a serious breakdown in the soil structure and it deserves, from the Advisory Committee established by this Bill, equal financial consideration with the more visually obvious areas.

Intensive cropping takes place in areas where sugar cane, vegetables, fruits, vines and other irrigated crops are grown and affects coastal regions of Queensland and irrigation areas of Victoria, New South Wales, South Australia and much of Tasmania. The problem of soil structure breakdown is beginning to be recognised by land owners, but I fear that far too little is being done to conserve the soils affected. This is very important because it is not visually obvious to people driving along roads; it is obvious only to the people who are working these intensive crop areas of Australia's farming industries. They understand that something is going on. For financial reasons, they are pushed to work the soil to the limit, and they do not know of avenues such as this for getting assistance. Even though we cannot actually see the problem, it is there and it is very detrimental. In my electorate of Braddon in Tasmania people are now having to plough down to about two feet to make sure that they break up the clay pan which is developing from overuse. As a nation we have to ensure that we do not let this go on to the same extent as we did with the salinity problem.

Another invisible factor of soil, which is critical to maintaining Australia's soil, is its chemical composition. Again, it is an invisible problem. We do not see it; it has to be analysed. The chemical composition of soil is complex and, as yet, it is not fully understood. Certainly it is not understand to the extent that we understand all the changes and consequences when any one factor in the soil is modified, let alone if several factors are modified. Certainly, as farming people, we are modifying many of these factors all at once, but we do not know the full implications of doing so. It is hoped that this Bill for financial assistance will remedy the degradation that is occurring.

I believe that the Advisory Committee, to be formed under Part IV of this Bill, should always have at least one person, and more if possible, who has had experience at the grass roots level of soil conservation; not just people who are well educated and who are in the bureaucracy, whether it be in the State, in institutional bodies or in the Federal Government, but people who have really worked the land and who understand it. It is only when we have such people on these types of committees that we can use the knowledge that is built up in resource banks around Australia for practical purposes and have it act for us. So often people who form such committees are well qualified on paper but lack the practical skills required to put their knowledge into practice. That is very important. Consequently, priorities are set and decisions taken without fully appreciating the problems and practicalities involved. So often we have policies developed by governments-not just by the present Government but sometimes by the coalition-that do not really get to the basic level of where things must operate.

Finally, the coalition is proud of its conservation record. I should like to highlight a few instances. The coalition parties developed the national conservation strategy for Australia. They increased protection for endangered species, including whales. They were involved in the control of sea and air pollution. They initiated reafforestation programs for Australia which, of course, are very important in preventing soil erosion. They were involved in the establishment of major national parks of world significance, such as the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park--

TALK.START.PARA: —What is in the record on South West Tasmania?

—If the honourable member for Reid comes to the debate this evening, he will hear me talking about the South West. The coalition supports world conservation strategies. To answer the honourable member, however, South West Tasmania has always been managed very well by the Tasmanian Government and its forestry department. I have just read some of the comments from the real impact study put out by the Forest Action Network, an arm of the Tasmanian Wilderness Society. When one reads some of these documents one starts to realise how ludicrous a lot of the statements are about the South West. I am enjoying reading some of that literature. I should like to say that the South West of Tasmania has always been managed very well by Tasmanian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —As many speakers have already said in this debate, soil is Australia's most valuable asset, after its people. Soil conservation is now urgent. I compliment the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) on his common-sense data, although I remind him that many farmers, the people about whom he speaks, are the most fervent conservationists. In fact, some farmers I have known have taken a lead in environmental movements, simply because of their close relations with the soil.

SPEECH.PARA: The Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Bill recognises the importance of government action in preventing soil erosion and also provides a statutory basis whereby the Commonwealth can contribute to soil conservation nationally. It will provide financial assistance to the States, the Commonwealth and other institutions, and to individuals for this purpose. The Bill also provides for a Soil Conservation Advisory Committee to provide advice to the Minister for Primary Industry concerning the allocation of financial assistance and the Commonwealth's role in soil conservation in general.

Soil erosion should concern all Australians because experts have warned that soil erosion is so bad that by the end of this century there will be one-third less soil per person than there is now. That will vitally affect the wellbeing of all Australians. Soil is the basis of our very existence. Most of our present wealth comes from being self-sufficient in agriculture and from lucrative rural exports. When we lose top-soil, we lose agricultural production. There are areas of Australia of rich fertile land now under pressure from severe soil degradation, resulting from intensive cropping and grazing, that could be virtually unproductive in as little as 50 years. A study initiated by the Whitlam Government resulted in a recommendation for the establishment of a national soil conservation program by the Federal Government. Despite the acute seriousness of the problem and these recommendations, the Fraser Government withdrew all Commonwealth funding for soil conservation in l980. In an unbelievable turn-around, the previous Government took back the entire $3m set aside for soil conservation three months after it had been allocated in the l980-8l Budget. How can members of a government that provided nothing for the urgent job of saving our life-sustaining soils be taken seriously on any matters to do with our primary producers? Not only did the previous Government cut all Commonwealth funding for essential conservation measures, but it continued to support tax arrangements, such as deductions for tree clearing, which encouraged felling when it was not required. The previous Government also failed to take notice, on some occasions, of environmental impact studies which were available to it.

This Government not only has eliminated tax measures that encouraged soil degradation but also has reinstated Commonwealth funding and a national involvement in soil conservation. It is listening to the voices of those who write the environmental impact studies. A national commitment first made by the Whitlam Labor Government, only to be abandoned by the succeeding Liberal-National Party Government, was to fund a national involvement in soil conservation.

As we come into the Budget period once again I challenge the perpetrators of Budget cost cutting to look at the enormous financial dividend returned to the economy by sound investment in soil conservation. Sir William McKell, as Labor Premier of New South Wales, recognised this in the 1940s and his programs in rural New South Wales prevented what would have been further tragic degradation of our lands. Under Labor, that State had one of the first soil conservation programs in the world. This rural support also had the side effect of keeping Labor in government in New South Wales for many years.

Two-thirds of the total land area of Australia is used for agriculture. No other land use even approaches this dominance in area used. The actual area of land disturbed by mining, for instance, is only around 320 square kilometres. A study undertaken by the then Department of Home Affairs and Environment in 1983 indicated that as much as 52 per cent of rural land in Australia needs treatment for land degradation. Twenty-two per cent can be treated by better management practices and the remaining 29 per cent needs treatment by works as well as management. The area already treated, only 2 per cent, is minute in comparison with the area still requiring treatment. That treated area includes my property-I should quickly add that it did so well before I came into Parliament-as a result of work done in New South Wales on the Googong catchment area for the city of Canberra.

I applaud the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) for recognising the urgent need for Commonwealth assistance in preventing further land degradation. Government soil conservation assistance and public awareness of the dangers of soil loss were made particularly important in Australia by the economic recession, which was felt most by the farming sector. Economic pressures on agricultural producers have in turn ultimately led to pressure on the land itself. Farmers have not been able to afford sufficient outlay on soil conservation measures and are often forced to stock to maximum capacity for a reasonable return.

In the electorate of Eden-Monaro there is widespread soil erosion, as in other parts of Australia. Particularly bad is the Monaro, where treeless paddocks show signs of severe soil degradation and recovery from each drought seems slower and slower. I include areas which have never grown trees, such as the Monaro frost plains. Eden-Monaro is fortunate, however, in having a very capable Soil Conservation Service. People working under the technical jobs for women program-Mary Bell is one from my electorate-along with other workers, such as Graeme Clifton, Greg Harris and Steven Eccles, form a hard-working team with their field officers in the Queanbeyan region, and in Cooma there is John Rogers, the district soil conservationist, and Corinne Unger. In Bombala, David Thomas and Matthew Corbett provide essential services that are designed to prevent the loss of our life-sustaining soils. These services depend on continued Commonwealth support for their overall effectiveness.

This Government has always recognised that devastating pressures are placed on the land by economic hardship. It has shown this through the reintroduction of a soil conservation program. There has been some alleviation of this pressure, first by the overcoming of the drought and then by the deregulation of the dollar, which has worked for better export markets.

It is important to understand the historical background to soil degradation. Without that understanding any attempt at forming a perspective on current land use pressures will not take into account some of the important causes of these pressures.

Before European settlement, land in Australia was grazed only by soft-footed marsupials and 'managed' by the Aboriginals through the use of fire and customs which dictated to some extent how and when animals and birds should be harvested and vegetation burned. An equilibrium existed between the land and its use. The use was sustainable. European settlement brought with it new and radically different forms of rural land use. Grazing pressures were greatly increased by the build-up of large numbers of sheep and cattle, and by the introduction of the rabbit. The use of fire changed, being used for short term gain to get rid of inedible dead vegetation and produce a green pick. Large scale clearing began. This capitalised on plant nutrients built up under previous ecosystems and was done without much regard to land degradation potential or long term effects.

However, if our pastures are well managed they will maintain their productivity, cover and composition. Those which are over-grazed or badly grazed will degenerate, with reductions in vegetative cover and the proportion of desirable species. A reduction in vegetative cover is the prime cause of land degradation in grazing areas. The soil, with its protective mantle reduced or lacking, becomes stripped of its surface layers through sheet erosion by water and wind. Runoff increases and drainage lines erode into gullies as a result of the increased flow. Gully erosion is accentuated where extensive tree clearing has occurred to make way for grazing. Such clearing may also result in increased sub-surface flow of water, leading to problems of tunnelling, salinity and even land slips.

The answer to some of our soil conservation problems caused by farm management practices is to discourage over-grazing practices by placing reasonable limits on stocking, to prevent unwise land clearing, to engage in a national awareness program, and to provide government assistance with stabilisation and preventative measures. Land has traditionally been regarded by European society as an indestructible object for ownership and use. Landowners used to be free to use and manage their land as they wished. These attitudes are now changing in several very important ways, not only within governments but also amongst land-holders themselves. The idea of stewardship is spreading. The landowner and society of today are beginning to be regarded as stewards of land with an obligation to consider the needs of future generations and to hand it on without loss of productivity or use potential. The traditional Aboriginal philosophy that 'the land doesn't belong to me, I belong to the land' is one we might ponder.

The land's limitation and fragility are becoming more appreciated. Australia does have very poor soil resources and I cannot stress too strongly the urgency of the need for soil conservation. We see television programs about people starving in drought-stricken Third World Africa and some parts of the Middle East. We provide short term, stop-gap assistance in the form of food aid, which is essential for the maintenance of life, but do we understand the fundamental cause of these famines? The starving refugees we see on television are a new type of refugee. They are not fleeing from wars or political oppression, although these often do cause famine, but from the barren earth itself. Their land, stripped by poor cultivation techniques and over-grazing, and subsequent poor rainfall, can no longer support them.

In Australia this Labor Government has reacted to the need to provide assistance to prevent soil degradation and our march towards ever-increasing unproductive areas of land and more devastating and frequent droughts. I therefore commend the Minister for Primary Industry for his foresight in introducing this Bill. The Government has provided $5m for soil conservation since coming to office. It has future generations in mind with the introduction of the Bill, and a desire to see that our land continues to provide us with sufficient food, and a healthy export income-not to mention rural-related employment for many thousands of Australians and a way of life that is free from turmoil. The Government is in partnership with the State governments, with local authorities and with the people who live on the land. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that all sections of the Parliament welcome the Government's efforts to address the problems that are affecting the farmlands of Australia. There is little doubt in anyone's mind that agriculture in particular is still one of the major producers of finance and overseas funds for the Australian economy. It is interesting to note that in my period as a government back bencher I made a speech in the grievance debate on this very subject on l9 August l982. On reading that speech again I find that all the things I said then are particularly relevant today. In that speech I reminded the House that in my electorate of O'Connor, which is basically the wheat belt of Western Australia, the percentage of salt-affected and wind-eroded land in particular is high and it is presenting great problems to agriculture in that State. I mentioned then:

SPEECH.PARA: The Western Australian Department of Agriculture has recently completed a salt land survey based on returns submitted in l979 by farm owners. The survey showed salt encroachment increased by 35 per cent per annum. A total of 263,753 hectares of previously arable land is now salt affected, which is l.75 per cent of the cleared farmland in Western Australia.
A more recent assessment, to which I will refer in a moment, talks of 2 per cent of cleared farmland. It is interesting to note also that I stated:
A further 378,000 hectares of land is classified naturally as saline.

That is a huge area of land. We are well aware of what that land can produce. There must be an absolute commitment on the part of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and the Government in this regard. Let me read from the Minister's second reading speech. He said:
This Bill will allow for the provision of financial assistance for soil conservation projects undertaken by the Commonwealth, by the States-
this is the point that pleases me most-
by individuals and non-government organisations. It also provides for a Soil Conservation Advisory Committee-

The whole push of the speech I made in August l982 was to identify that the people in Western Australia who had done the most to address the problem of salinity in the farmlands in my electorate were the individuals and the non-government organisations. In fact I was at pains-I was later criticised by the Director of Agriculture in Western Australia for my pains-to give a layman's opinion that, of those who were active in the field, the Western Australian Department of Agriculture came last in terms of effectiveness. I have a cousin who is deeply involved in that Department so I was not even being protective of the family when I said that. That was a decision I had come to which was in contrast with another speech I had made in this place where I had been very congratulatory of the Western Australian Department of Agriculture on its efforts to combat another scourge that we now know as rye grass toxicity. I was trying to take that Department's efforts on an individual basis.

Governments, by nature, tend to want to give money to other governments. I am arguing very strongly today that the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee should be looking very closely in Western Australia at least at the efforts of the private sector-the farmers and the non-government organisations. In this regard, the Whittington Interceptor Salt Affected Land Treatment Society, known as the WISALTS group, has addressed this problem and has been effective in resolving the problem of salinity in particular. It is interesting also to note that I received correspondence just the other day from Kojonup, where a group of private citizens sought a community employment program grant to try to effect some reafforestation, which is one of the necessary aspects of any soil conservation. But they were told that, because that was on private land, it did not fit the guidelines. To be quite honest, if we are going into the field of spending government money to create jobs-private land or not-I can see no better way of spending some of that CEP money than to take people out on to the land, show them the problem and get them to help rectify it by tree planting. I think it is quite silly for government members to make the statement that somebody else might gain. The biggest gain to the community would be in two areas: Increasing the amount of land that could go back into productivity and, of course, teaching young people some form of employment. I think it is time that we looked a little further at how we spend CEP money. Its primary purpose is to create jobs. I think they should be created in the most productive and effective way. Land conservation is certainly such a program.

The WISALTS group in Western Australia, which was related originally to the efforts of Mr Harry Whittington, who resides in my electorate, recognised that it was not correct, as the Agriculture Department claimed, that the problem generally was the result of rising watertables. It was a problem of waterlogging caused by the removal of trees and the lack of growth that would otherwise have either used the water or held it on the slopes. The Western Australian Department of Agriculture has argued that the water finds its way down into the subsoils and this raises the level of the watertable. The WISALTS people say that that is not so, that the water flows generally along the surface, or just below the surface, and eventually it gets to the lowest point and waterlogs and compacts the ground. Salinity is the result of the evaporation of that water. Both sides still agree to disagree on that. My observations are that, generally in the drier areas, WISALTS is right. Its approach is different from the Department's approach of trying to plant some salt tolerant and very low value feed, trees or something that will grow in those conditions but provide very little productivity. The Department has stated that the land continues not to support crops. I have seen crops growing on land that just two years ago was salt affected. Since I have been a member of parliament I have seen an area of land that was completely non-productive become productive. I will refer to the treatment of that area later.

The WISALTS group literally has put up contour banks. It has appointed and trained its own surveyors. It put up contour banks to hold the water on the slopes, to stop it from running to the lowest point. This has been quite successful but it is not the total answer. This group has achieved major successes and it has put a lot of land back into production. Mr Whittington, who experimented with this matter 30 years ago, had reached a stage where the land on which his home was built was about to be engulfed by salt. That property is now highly productive. That is just a single effort. Today the WISALTS group has almost l,000 members. Those members are ideological and they almost treat their business as a religion. When we see what they have achieved we cannot blame them for that. They are very committed people. I think they need support. I am putting a case for them in this debate today. As this is a non-government organisation in which individuals are involved, I am hoping that substantial amounts of money that would otherwise be directed to the Western Australian department will find their way to these people. They have been successful and, in my mind, their theories work.

The other group that is very active in Western Australia operates around the Watheroo area north of Perth where there is a substantially higher watertable. That group is proposing to drain the land to get rid of the water. It is doing this by excavating natural creeks. In recent times it has reached a point where a private enterprise operator has put in quite substantial machinery to do that. He has become an expert. I recently had the pleasure of assisting him in the importation of a laser-operated Canadian plough which will lay the proper plastic agricultural drainage pipes dead level underground. At one stage this plough was going to attract $l0,000-worth of duty, which I thought was a little improper considering the purpose for which it is to be used. I am pleased to say that the Australian Customs Service was able to agree with my submissions. That plough was eventually imported at the 2 per cent flat duty rate which saved this contractor a substantial amount of money. He is now laying a plastic pipe for that underground drainage.

That is much more in line with what the Department of Agriculture sees as the answer to the problem, but I am pointing out that this is in much wetter country. The WISALTS proposal seems to work extremely well in the drier areas. Incidentally, holding the water up on the banks also creates large quantities of stock water, which is also required. It is an extremely interesting proposal to recover land.

A submission from WISALTS which was sent to the Minister on 11 February talks about a lot of the problems that it believes are of concern to the farmers in West Australia. It says that waterlogging is a problem that has been created by clearing. I think it has also been created, to a great degree, by other government entities-the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee should be looking at this-by the people who make our roads and our railway lines.

In my electorate one does not have to drive very far along a road before one comes across a section that has been raised slightly, with a substantial area of salt degradation on one side. It is there because the road has stopped the water following its natural course. We have done this throughout Australia, particularly with railway lines, where we are trying to keep the line as level as possible.

It is natural for an engineer to protect his railway line or his road. If he thinks a bit of water is flowing through there, he will build up the road. Australia being a fairly flat country, and Western Australia in particular, we have a situation where there are shallow depressions along which water flowed naturally in the days of the forest, the kangaroo and the Aboriginal, to which the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) referred. Water found its way to the creeks and the sea through very shallow depressions. We have blocked off a lot of them. Only a substantial aerial photography program will identify those problems for us. The road and rail authorities have to get back to letting the water flow along. We are well aware of some of the problems that have been created in our cities and our metropolitan areas by people saying, 'Oh, the water flows there. I can soon fix that. I will build a house on a substantial foundation'. They block it off and suddenly half the countryside is flooded. This is a common practice and it should cease.

The WISALTS submission then talks about soil degradation and the declining levels of soil health, as well as the declination of balanced pastures, with poor quality grasses becoming dominant-just another problem in all this-and reduced pasture production. I must identify this situation. When we talk about soil conservation, surely we are talking about returning it to productivity, not putting it aside and trying to grow some useless product on it. In the Watheroo area when I was first introduced to their method of attacking the problem, I was taken into an area of probably 200 acres which the farmer had just set about draining properly. I was back there when the plough I just mentioned was given its first test run. We walked on to that land and all but about five acres was growing barley about one metre high. That is excellent. I cannot quote many examples of such speedy recovery of land. Yet the farmer told me that the land was like that when he took over the farm from his father and for as long as he could remember as a child. There are methods available to alleviate this problem. I am sure that the Committee the Minister proposes will go a long way towards that, provided it goes past the government sector and talks to the various groups which have had success in Western Australia. No doubt there are groups in other States as well.

The submission from WISALTS indicates concern about reduced grain yields and says that Western Australia's production is being maintained by increased plantings and not by increased productivity, which is happening throughout the world. It refers to the leaching of nutrients that goes with this problem. We know that dying trees result in wind erosion. WISALTS tenth and last concern is lack of co-operation between farmers, scientists and others working in the field in researching solutions to the problems in the field. This submission has been made by this dedicated group who have given of their time to solve a problem in both their own and the community's interest. These people have made some suggestions for action by the Federal Government to encourage land users in conservation practices which I would like to put forward from their submission. They are: Continuation of an increase in allocation of Budget moneys for soil conservation-something this Bill is doing- consideration--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m. the debate is interrupted in accordance with Sessional Order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.
—I call the honourable member for Tangney.
—Mr Speaker, I do not think the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations is here. Is he on strike?
—The honourable member should proceed with his question or I will call someone else.
—On a point of order, Mr Speaker. The Minister has a responsibility to be here for Question Time.
—Order! It is not the responsibility of the Chair to enforce that.

—I ask a question of the Prime Minister. Now that the blockade of Queensland has started, does the Federal Government still stand squarely with the unions against the people of Australia who reside in Queensland?

—It is a great pity that those on the other side of the House cannot exhibit to the Australian people that they have a real interest in this issue rather than their continuous political posturing with no concern for the real issue. I said yesterday and I repeat it in this House that I and this Government do not believe that all right is on the side of the unions in this dispute. In this, as in just about every industrial dispute that exists in this country, there is normally an allocation of right and wrong on both sides of the dispute. This dispute is no different in that respect. In that case, if one is serious about wanting to settle the dispute and not trying to score political points, one adopts the course of procedure which is most likely and most calculated to achieve that result. The course of action which is most likely to bring about a resolution of this dispute in favour of the people of Queensland and of the people of Australia is for the two governments with a concern, that is, the Queensland Government and the Federal Government, to sit down with those on the union side who are capable of bringing influence to bear. In those circumstances, if the two governments were to sit down--
—Well, why don't you talk to the unions?
—Order! The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.

—If that were to occur, if the Government of Queensland were to sit down with us, no interests of the people of Queensland and no part of the public interest in Queensland would be disadvantaged. No part of the public interest would be disadvantaged if the two governments were to sit down together. If we are looking at the public interest, there is only one way in which that public interest can be served and that is to try to get to a position in which there can be negotiation. All the evidence of history, including that period of history when these miserable people on the other side of the House had responsibility for the regulation of industrial relations in this country, shows that ultimately the two sides to a dispute have to sit down and talk. No dispute is ever resolved until the two sides sit down and talk. The previous Government's record was abysmal.
—Well, why don't you talk to the unions?
—Order! The Leader of the National Party has been given a good deal of tolerance because of his position. I suggest that he set an example.

—As I have said, the record of history shows that ultimately the two sides have to talk. It is much more sensible and much more in the interests of the people of Australia and the people of Queensland that that process of negotiation and talking starts sooner rather than later. All the powers and the resources of this Government are available, without allocation of blame in this matter, to do just that. If that course is followed, we can soon resolve this dispute.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Transport. I refer the Minister to the answer he gave to the House yesterday concerning the allocation of record levels of funding to be made available for road construction and maintenance next year. Can the Minister inform the House of the allocation to be made to local governments for roads which are under their control and for which the continuity of guaranteed funding is so important?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for McMillan for his question. It is a very important issue, the level of funding from Federal governments--
—Why don't you make a statement about it?
—I warn the Leader of the National Party.

—The level of funding to local government to work on local or council roads is a very important issue. The honourable member's question is similar to matters raised yesterday by the honourable member for Herbert. Councils across Australia are under increasing pressure to meet their responsibilities for improved road systems. Some of the councils in some of the States have revenue limits set for them so their ability to raise revenue to increase expenditure is fixed. That causes problems for them. In some States there is an overflow of traffic from arterial roads because of inadequate levels of expenditure by the States concerned; that contributes to the burden. In addition to that, there has been residential development which may not have been planned for in the road systems.

ANSWER.PARA: If the Ministers for roads in Queensland, New South Wales and particularly Victoria had their way, the level of Federal expenditure for local government would be reduced next year. What they are asking this Government to do is to give less money to local government and to spend less money on the national highway system. To the honourable member for Herbert, the honourable member for Capricornia and the honourable member for Leichhardt, in Queensland the national highways are the Bruce Highway to the north and the Landsborough Highway to the west; in New South Wales it is the New England Highway and the Sydney-Newcastle expressway; it is the Hume Highway in Victoria and New South Wales; for South Australia and the Northern Territory it is the Stuart Highway. What those State Ministers want is for us to reduce the level of expenditure there, give less money to local government and give that additional money to the State Ministers for roads so that they can dispense their largesse at our expense and at the expense of local government and of the national highway system. Frankly, that is not on.

We will maintain the real level of expenditure on the national highway system to the end of the land transport program. From next year we will maintain the real level of expenditure to local government under the new land transport program. That will make a major difference for local government. I deplore the utterances by the State Ministers for roads and the approach that they are taking. Local government has its responsibilities. We will make sure that it is assisted in carrying out those responsibilities. I just remind the States that building and maintaining the roads system is a joint responsibility. It is a partnership of Federal government, State government and local government. This Government has lifted its share of expenditure to about 40 per cent. We have lifted our game and it is up to the States to do the same.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to the Australian Council of Trade Unions reported hit list of 5l companies employing tens of thousands of people who are to be subjected to alleged guerrilla attacks by trade unions. I ask the Minister: Will he act against this campaign of industrial lawlessness or will the Government once again abdicate its responsibilities to Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In dealing with responsibilities in this place, I state that responsibilities rest not only on the Government but also on the Opposition. If the Opposition were really concerned about this matter and not concerned just to make political capital out of it, it would use its special relationship with the Queensland Government to try to bring about a change of approach on the part of that Government and try to bring about a situation in which this dispute could be settled. The Leader of the Opposition knows that he could take action to get the Premier of Queensland to try to change his approach in a way which would simply be for him to agree to discuss this whole matter with the ACTU. That would mean that there would be no hit lists and no blockade and that all this industrial action would be off. He is in a better position than the Government to influence the Bjelke-Petersen Government and he is refusing to do so. So the Opposition should not say that we are not carrying out our responsibilities. We are most certainly--
—Order! The House will come to order. I have warned a number of honourable members to cease interjecting. If the interjections persist, I intend to name the next offender without further warning.

—The Government has been thoroughly responsible in its approach to this matter. It has devised a means of ensuring that there is no blockade and no industrial action. Any reasonable government would have accepted that as being a way of avoiding such action because there would be no loss of face for that government at all. It simply means that the government would have to discuss with the trade union movement the way in which the dispute would be settled and listen to approaches which could be put to it. If the Opposition in this place were constructive and responsible it would be encouraging the Queensland Government to take that approach. What it is doing, however, is simply seeking to make as much political capital as it can from this whole matter.

ANSWER.PARA: This Government adheres to its approach. It is a thoroughly responsible approach. We will not be going down the path of adopting draconian measures in order to try to settle this dispute because that would not succeed. The Opposition knows it would not succeed. What it would do would be certainly to move us into a situation of a massive national confrontation. That is something which the Opposition probably thinks would be a good thing to happen. However, certainly this Government is not in the business of bringing that about. Our actions are responsible. We are taking all the action which can be expected of a Federal Government to prevent this blockade and industrial action. We have proposed a constructive approach. We call on the Opposition to change its policy and to try to influence the Queensland Government to see reason. If it had any responsibility that is what it would do.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Housing and Construction. Does the current state of dwelling approval and lending figures show that the prediction of the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry of l47,000 dwelling commencements for l984-85 will be met?

—Yes, the Government does expect that the figure of 147,000 dwelling commencements predicted by the Indicative Planning Council for this year will be met. That figure compares very favourably with the abysmal figure of 105,000 dwelling commencements achieved by the Opposition in the last year that it was in government. If one compares the figures for private housing approvals for the 12 months to February 1985 with the figures to February 1984, one finds that they rose by 14.8 per cent. Approvals for private flats and units rose by a massive 40.8 per cent. From January 1984 to January 1985 the number of housing loans for all significant lenders rose by 17.5 per cent. Figures for savings banks rose by 22 per cent and those for permanent building societies rose by 26 per cent. In the three-months period leading up to January 1985, compared with the same period to January 1984, figures for savings banks were up by 16.4 per cent at the expense of the building societies, whose figures were down by 15 per cent. This shows that, as the savings banks experience an easing of the recent exceptional increase in the rate of deposit growth to a more conventional long term figure, the permanent building societies should be exceptionally well placed to pick up their lending rates.

—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. On an issue such as this the custom of this place has been that statements be made to the House. The Minister is obviously reading from prepared notes. I suggest that this is an issue we would like to debate. Would it not be more appropriate if the Minister made a statement in this place instead of answering a Dorothy Dix question?
—Order! That is not a point of order; it is a matter of opinion.

—I was saying that approval rates by local government authorities and lending rates indicate that we will reach the level of l47,000 dwelling commencements which the IPC predicted for l984-85. This is in direct contrast to the boom-bust figures achieved by the previous Government. Back in l980-8l the previous Government achieved the respectable figure of l49,000 dwelling commencements, only to see it crash to l05,000 in l8 months-a boom figure and a bust figure. Our policies have increased commencements from 105,000 to l37,000 dwelling commencements in l983-84. We expect to reach l47,000 this year and l39,000 or l40,000 in l985-86, which shows that we not only are achieving growth in the industry but also are achieving stability. That is what the industry wants.
—Mr Speaker, I ask the Minister to table the document or cue cards from which he has just been reading.
—Was the Minister quoting from a document on public affairs?
—I was referring to my own notes, Mr Speaker.
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. I refer you to standing order 32l wherein the words used are, 'documents of a confidential nature', not a 'document on public affairs'.

—I refer the honourable member to House of Representatives Practice and also to the ruling given by my predecessor, Sir Billy Snedden, on this matter when the matter was one of two questions. One question was whether the document was a document on public affairs. If it was, the question was whether it was confidential. If it was confidential, the papers were not tabled. I should also add that there was a clear statement in that ruling that it did not apply to a member's personal notes.

—I ask the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations: In light of the Minister's refusal, the Prime Minister's refusal and the Government's refusal to protect the people of Queensland from the effects of the action of militant trade unions, what does the Minister intend to say to the tens of thousands of employees and the thousands of shareholders of the companies that are being targeted by unions for this especially vindictive persecution? The entire House knows, the entire country knows--
—Order! The honourable member is entitled to ask a question, not to make a speech. Has he come to the point of his question or does he intend to continue in the same vein?
—Everyone knows that the Government has the power under the Trade Practices Act. Why does it not use that power?
—Order! The honourable member for Tangney will resume his seat.

—The honourable member for Tangney works on the presumption that taking action involving the use of draconian legislation by this Government would resolve this dispute. That is a patently false assumption. On the contrary, it is the view of this Government that the use of that kind of approach would lead to a much greater industrial conflagration than we are heading towards as a result of the actions of the Queensland Government. I repeat: If we are to resolve this matter, the solution quite simply is in the hands of the Queensland Government. Rather than putting it on this Government to take action which would only worsen the situation, Opposition members would be much better off approaching the Queensland Government to act reasonably in this matter. The double standards of the Opposition are also something which need to be highlighted in this place. We see great concern about the effect on people of industrial action by trade unions. But, as the Prime Minister pointed out yesterday, there was no such concern when doctors took action in New South Wales to affect the rights of Australian citizens living in New South Wales, to use the terminology of the honourable member for Tangney. Indeed, honourable members opposite encouraged them and said they fully supported them in their actions. So the Opposition has totally double standards in this matter. It has no credit whatever from this whole episode.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. What is the Government's strategy for ensuring that the potential benefits of depreciation are not eroded by inflation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. As I emphasised recently, the recent depreciation of the Australian dollar provides an opportunity for us to correct current account balance problems and to promote further sustained growth in domestic production and employment. It is quite clear that the challenge to us as a society is to prevent the initial rise in consumer prices leading to some inflationary spiral which would erode the potential benefits of depreciation. It is quite clear that all parties in this community need to share in some degree the initial processes of adjustment.

ANSWER.PARA: Fortunately for Australia this Government, in responding to this challenge, is able to work within the processes of the prices and incomes accord, an accord which, I remind members of this House, has produced the following results: It has resulted in a halving of the inflation rate we inherited from the incompetent economic managers sitting opposite. It has led to substantial increases in employment as against the record unemployment under their policies. As I pointed out earlier, in 23 months we achieved within the framework of the prices and incomes accord an increase of 34l,000 in the employment figures. It took 23 months for us to do it, but it took honourable members opposite 88 months to do it. Also, under the operation of the prices and incomes accord we have had the production of a situation in which we have had the lowest level of industrial disputation in this country for l7 years and the restoration of profitability to the levels of the late l960s and early l970s.

We have the opportunity, and we will exercise the opportunity, of working, in regard to the questions posed by the devaluation of the Australia dollar, within the accord that has produced that result. I ask the House to recall what happened in l976.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order l45, which deals with relevance. The Prime Minister is now making a speech in answer to a Dorothy Dix question. I ask that he make his answer more relevant to his stature-short.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—The community will contrast the capacity of this Government to deal with this problem within the framework of the accord with what happened after the l976 devaluation, when the Fraser Government, after a significant devaluation, slammed on the fiscal and monetary brakes. It did that because it had no other framework within which to operate. Subsequently the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, with some benefit of hindsight, said: 'The problem with us was that we had no incomes policy'. Of course, he was right. I would have thought that, having diagnosed the problem, the Opposition would have had the good sense to say now: 'We need an incomes policy'. It does not have one.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition would return this country to the disastrous situation that operated in l98l-82. I remind the House of the disastrous situation regarding the metal trades round under the previous Government's lack of policy. Awards grew by l6.9 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 85, which deals with tedious repetition. The Prime Minister has given this speech l0 times in the last three weeks.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I can well understand that it is tedious for the honourable member. One thing that the Australian people would not want would be the tedious repetition of what happened in l98l-82, because what happened then under the approach of honourable members opposite--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! A general warning has been given. Some honourable members have not been observing it. They have one last chance.

—In the absence of policy, awards grew by l6.9 per cent in the year to March l982. During l982 inflation was more than l0 per cent. Employment figures fell by l86,000 in the last year of the Fraser Government, and there were historically high levels of industrial disputation. The simple fact is-it is about time the Opposition understood it; the Australian people understand it-that there is only one framework within which one can have any policy designed to deal with the problems of devaluation and that is within a centralised wage system. It is within that system that policy can be applied. How can one possibly talk about applying an economic policy if one has abandoned a whole incomes policy situation and said that wages and salaries in this country will be determined not within a centralised system but by allowing negotiation and the exercising of bargaining strength to take place in industry after industry and in enterprise after enterprise? How can any policy approach be applied in that framework? The Australian people have witnessed and have suffered from the bankruptcy of economic policy of those who sit opposite. They have benefited from the operation of the prices and incomes accord. They have been protected. Their interests have been advanced. That will continue to occur under the policies of this Government in this year and beyond.

—Does the Prime Minister regard the continuation of at least the current profit share as being critical to the maintenance of present employment levels? If so, will he assure the House that the Government will strenuously oppose any wage increases on productivity grounds which will have as a consequence any erosion of the current profit share?
—Tell us what you did to profit shares?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a line ball between my good friend and colleague the Treasurer and me as to who derives the most amusement when the honourable member for Bennelong gets up and asks questions about the management of the economy. The honourable gentleman presided over the most calamitous decline in the Australian economy, including the most calamitous decline in profit levels, in this country since the Great Depression. As Treasurer, he was the man who had control and prime responsibility for economic policy, including looking after the question of the levels of profitability. What happened in that case? He had all the control but we had the worst recession for 50 years, profit levels went down and people were being sacked. This was being done all the time on the basis of his espoused policy of controlling inflation first.

ANSWER.PARA: Did he have any success in controlling inflation first? It went through the roof. He failed in terms of controlling inflation. As he mismanipulated economic, fiscal and monetary policy, with no incomes policy at all, he not only failed to achieve his primary objective but also brought about the worst level of unemployment that this country had experienced for 50 years. After two years of economic management under the responsibility of the world's best Treasurer--
Honourable members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition said something about a stewards inquiry. He knows where a stewards inquiry is needed. I refer to Queensland. I would not talk about that if I were him. Let us just test the relative performance of the honourable member for Bennelong when he had the responsibility for economic policy against what has happened under this Government and with this Treasurer. The Opposition had inflation running at ll.2 per cent, double the average of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. What has the Government done? It has halved inflation and got it down to the OECD average. What did the Opposition do about unemployment? It had it at levels above l0 per cent; the Government has got it down. What happened in regard to the creation of jobs? The Opposition took 88 months to create 340,000 jobs. The Treasurer did it with this Government's policies in 23 months. What has happened under this Government in regard to the levels of profitability? The economic policies of this Government have halved inflation and brought about the highest rate of employment growth ever recorded while halving inflation. At the same time, under this Government there was a restoration of the levels of company profitability for the first time, including the seven years of Liberal Government, back to the levels at the end of the 1960s.

ANSWER.PARA: These things have not happened by accident. They have happened because this Government has a coherent view of economic policy making within which the instruments of wages policy, monetary policy and a fiscal policy are integrated. Because we so integrate those instruments we have been able to produce those results which make the Opposition's performance look so abysmal. We are not going to abandon that approach of coherent economic policy making. We will continue to apply that policy in a way which will continue to produce the results.

Let me finally make this point: We are continually conscious of the fact that the health of the Australian economy depends very much upon the health of the private sector. I have consistently said that we recognise the fact that three-quarters of the Australian jobs are provided by the private sector. Therefore, it is fundamentally important that the private sector be healthy and profitable. As distinct from the Opposition's rhetoric, when it talked about profits but only plunged this country into bankruptcy and put more and more businesses out of work, we do not go on with the rhetoric; we produce the goods and will continue to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism who is at present representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer the Minister to an article published in the Australian Financial Review on l5 April l985 concerning the apparent rejection by the Steel Industry Authority of any recommendation to cut protection for the Australian steel industry. Can the Minister advise, first, what is the current position in respect of the market share enjoyed by cold rolled strip and sheet products? Secondly, what effect has the removal of the developing country preferences had on this sector of the market? Thirdly, what further action is proposed to fulfil the Government's commitment to the steel industry plan in respect of these products?

—I commend the honourable member for his question-a legitimate question without notice, I might add. As the purpose of Question Time is to provide information, and as the honourable member is obviously vitally interested in a proper answer to this question-and quite deservedly so, as he represents a large steel region-rather than give my view of the answer, I will take the question on notice. I will refer it to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce for a full and comprehensive answer.

—I refer the Prime Minister to the story in today's Australian Financial Review in which the world's best Treasurer is reported to be denying his Cabinet colleagues access to the economic figures compiled by the joint economic forecasting group. I ask the Prime Minister whether these figures are important to a proper consideration of the Budget and whether, in the interests of good government and business confidence, he will intercede to ensure that this information is provided to Cabinet Ministers who are involved in areas of macro-economic policy, in particular to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, who was a Treasurer. Does he share the view of his current Treasurer that even his most senior Cabinet colleagues should not have access to such vital information?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not altogether surprised that there is a question on this subject. I want to say quite straightforwardly that I have had correspondence from the two Ministers concerned and I am considering the matter. Indeed, Cabinet will consider it and a decision will be made. Let me say, however, that I assume that what is in the mind of the honourable member because he would not be trying to score some nasty little partisan point--
—Nor would you.

—No. He would be concerned to try to get an understanding of what is done about making available publicly information in the economic field, so that the people of Australia will have an opportunity to understand properly what is happening. As I know that that is the thrust of the honourable member's question, not some miserable concern with petty point scoring, there are a couple of points I would like to make.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of this Government being in office, the Budget documents now contain a richer set of information than has ever been available before to the people of Australia-more information than ever before. Not only do we have that situation, but also the Treasurer and I regularly make available in public speeches a range of information which is relevant to the operation of the Australian economy. We have institutionalised, in the form of the Economic Planning Advisory Council, a framework whereby there will be the dissemination of information beyond just a few privileged individuals in the bureaucracy. Information will be made available to the major elements in the economic decision making process in the community.

I conclude on this point: If members of the Opposition, vicariously through the honourable member for Forde, want to advocate the release of detailed and conditional economic forecasts by officials, there is one very simple question which they need to put to themselves: Why did they not do it themselves when they were in government for seven years?

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister whether he is aware of recent reports that Queensland's economic performance is lagging far behind that of other States. If so, does he see any relationship between this fact and the fanatical attitude towards industrial relations adopted recently by the Queensland Premier? Furthermore, could this in turn, in his opinion, have any carry-over effects on our national economic situation?
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The question asked for the Prime Minister's opinion. That is not permitted under the Standing Orders.
—I did not see the question as asking for an opinion.
—He used that expression.

—Those words in fact were included in my question. I will rephrase that last part of the question to satisfy the honourable member for Wentworth. Furthermore, could this in turn-I will drop those little words that upset the honourable member for Wentworth-have any carry-over effect on our national economic situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand why honourable members opposite will adopt any subterfuge or attempt to avoid the facts coming out. When the facts do come out in the answer that I will give, members of not only this House, but also the Australian public, will have very considerable cause to start to ask some serious questions about what is happening in Queensland. I said to this House a couple of weeks ago, as we saw the beginning of the creation of this state of siege as a result of the actions of the Queensland Premier, that what we were seeing was an attempt to divert attention from the fact, which is becoming increasingly obvious, that the Queensland Premier and his Government are the worst economic managers in Australia. So that honourable members opposite and the people of Australia can have the chance to test that assertion, I ask the House to take note of these economic indicators, against which they can make a judgment about what is happening in Queensland and why the Queensland Premier is attempting to divert attention.

ANSWER.PARA: Let the House take note of these statistics. Let us look at employment, and I guess we would all agree that that is a pretty fundamental indicator. Comparing the l2-month period to March l985 with the same period to March l984, we find that the Australian picture shows an increase in employment of 2 per cent; in Queensland the increase is 0.3 per cent. Now let us look at the other side of the coin. What has happened in unemployment? In the same period the Australian picture shows a decline in unemployment of 4.l per cent, while in Queensland there has been an increase of 7.3 per cent.

Let us have a look at another significant indicator-the registrations of new motor vehicles over the three months to February l985 compared with the three months to February l984. In Australia there has been an ll.9 per cent increase while in Queensland there has been a 0.5 per cent decline. Now let us look at the number of new dwellings approved. The Australian picture shows an increase of 9.5 per cent while in Queensland the increase is only l.7 per cent. As to the value of other building approvals, in the three months to January l985 compared with the same period in the previous year, the Australian picture shows 67.4 per cent, the Queensland picture, 36.8 per cent. For new dwelling commencements for the September quarter of l984 compared with the September quarter of l983, the Australian figure is 27.l per cent and the Queensland figure is l3.9 per cent. The one statistic-I will not leave it out-which gives Queensland a slightly better picture is the value of retail sales.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. I submit to you that this is an abuse of Question Time. The Prime Minister is giving lengthy and extended answers to prevent members asking further questions. Secondly, he is not game to make a statement which can be debated. I submit that it is an abuse, Mr Speaker.
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member is well aware of the Standing Orders relating to answers.

—I admit I was under a misapprehension. I thought that the honourable member for Denison was getting up to claim that there was no way in the world that Queensland could take the title away from Tasmania; but it is possible. I want to be completely fair because there is just one statistic for this period in which Queensland has done a little better, and that is in the value of retail sales. Queensland did slightly better than the Australian average, with 9.9 per cent compared with 7.3 per cent for Australia as a whole.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us look quickly at the last four relevant indicators. For actual new fixed capital expenditure, the Australian picture for the September l984 quarter compared with the previous year shows an increase of 2.3 per cent; in Queensland the figure is down by 20.6 per cent.
