What about the question of working days lost due to industrial disputes? In the l2 months to January l985 compared with the previous l2 months-I urge honourable members opposite to listen to this-in Australia there was a fall of l5.6 per cent while in Queensland the figure was up by 83.9 per cent. The figures for working days lost per 1,000 employees due to industrial disputes are 6.4 per cent in Australia and 80.2 per cent in Queensland.

Finally-the fact that this is final makes it no less important; if one has a glimmering of understanding this figure might stick in the gullet most-let us have a look at what has happened in relation to bankruptcies. Opposition members talk about companies and the private sector, so let us see what has happened in this area in Australia and in Queensland in the l2 months to December l984 compared with the l2 months to December 1983. As a result of the economic policies of this Government, there has been a decline in bankruptcies in Australia of 8.2 per cent. What has happened in Queensland? There has been an increase of 26.4 per cent. When we look through that range of relevant comprehensive economic statistics, it is little wonder that the Premier and the Government of Queensland are trying to divert attention from the gross ineptitude of their economic management.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister to table the document from which he quoted.
—The document is tabled.
—My question is directed to the Treasurer. The Prime Minister predicted a lowering of interest rates in l985. When will this commence?

—Apparently George wants to tell me about his interest rate record. I am quite happy to go over that. His Government managed to bring about the highest level of nominal interest rates in Australian history. One only has to ask someone who is paying a mortgage or funding a business whether he wants to pay 23 or 22 per cent for that money-or l6 or l5 per cent. One will soon get the answer. I have answered questions on this matter on a number of occasions in the Parliament. I do not want to say too much more than I have said in the past. I was asked in the election campaign whether I agreed with the views of most market commentators about an interest rate step fall ahead in Australia in l985. I said that, after the tax rundown period, basically I agreed with the views of those commentators. I stick to that comment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report, dated 24 September 1984, provided to me by the Auditor-General pursuant to section 63P of the Audit Act, on the conduct of the audit of accounts and records of the National Aboriginal Conference. I seek leave to make a statement in respect of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, the report of the Auditor-General was tabled in this place. On pages 223 to 224 of that report the Auditor-General has informed the Parliament of an Audit he conducted last year of the records and accounts of the National Aboriginal Conference. That audit was made at my request because I became aware of serious deficiencies in the financial and related procedures of the NAC. The Auditor-General's report confirms the concerns I then had. However, I now feel it appropriate to provide to the Parliament the full text of the Auditor-General's report to me so that the public and all National Aboriginal Conference members may be completely informed of the nature of his inquiries and their outcome.

SPEECH.PARA: Consistent with the principles of Aboriginal self-management, to which both this Government and honourable members opposite have subscribed, I have supported the NAC to the maximum and have been most reluctant to look behind its conduct of its own affairs. However, when it became apparent last year that severe deficiencies in financial administration were being experienced, I arranged with the NAC an agency arrangement under which officers of my Department were provided to the NAC. These officers assumed a shared responsibility for financial and administrative matters. The report which I have just presented to the House shows quite clearly that the financial administration of the NAC commenced to improve substantially once my Department's agency arrangement was in place.

I announced on 2 April that the NAC would be terminated as from 30 June this year. Necessary administrative and financial arrangements to give effect to that decision are now being made. The administrative and financial difficulties experienced by the NAC were of course a factor in the Government's decision to terminate the NAC, but other factors were of more importance. A prime consideration was the finding by Dr Coombs, in his report which I presented to this House on 27 February this year, that the NAC was not adequately representative of Aboriginal community opinions and aspirations. As I said in my statement of 2 April, the new organisation to replace the NAC will be more closely based on Aboriginal community aspirations. Consultations with Aboriginal community groups and organisations now under way are devoted to that end. I present the following paper:
National Aboriginal Conference-Report and Ministerial Statement, 17 April 1985.
Motion (by Mr Young) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Auditor-General tabled today by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) on the National Aboriginal Conference is a massive indictment of the National Aboriginal Conference. It is an absolute disgrace and it shows a real and serious abuse of funds and public moneys by the National Aboriginal Conference. It is also a serious indictment of the Minister and his administration of his Department and the National Aboriginal Conference through his Department.

SPEECH.PARA: The report shows massive negligence by the NAC. The Minister has obviously known for some considerable time that all was not well at the NAC. He knew of the problem and my colleague the former shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), has endorsed my criticism. The Minister knew of the problem but time and again he put off making a decision. He has been hiding behind the philosophy of self-determination and self-management to excuse himself and his Department from gross incompetence in failing to oversee and manage funds appropriated to the NAC through his Department. The Minister and the Government nearly doubled the funds available to the NAC in the first Budget of this Government-an 87.42 per cent increase. Any organisation would have difficulty in absorbing such an increase. One would think that the Minister and the Department would have put procedures in train to see that those funds were expended properly but they were negligent in not seeing that this money was well spent and that appropriate audit procedures were followed.

It is interesting that the Minister has not yet revealed when he first knew that all was not well at the NAC. The Auditor-General's report and investigation were requested in March 1984. I ask the Minister in the House today to tell us when he first knew of the maladministration of the National Aboriginal Conference. The whole NAC business is a saga because the Minister has failed to exercise proper ministerial responsibility throughout the investigation into the future of the NAC. First, in July 1983 he commissioned Dr Coombs to report on the NAC. That report was presented to the Minister in May 1984, recommending the abolition of the NAC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nearly a year ago.

—Nearly a year ago, as my colleague interjects. Despite this the Minister did nothing until July last year when he commissioned a task force-again putting off a decision-to investigate the Coombs report, to investigate the restructuring of the NAC. Another nine months or more passed until, without notice, the NAC was unceremoniously abolished without a replacement body being announced and without any alternative proposal. Everyone knows that all is not well. We have seen that the Minister is incompetent and here he is just putting off the matter and duck-shoving. We do not know what the replacement body will be. During these months of the Minister's indecision and procrastination the NAC is being allowed to indulge in gross mismanagement and in a waste of public moneys. Part of this I think is due to the Minister's obsession with and pursuit of uniform land rights across this nation. This obsession has not only created a backlash and divisions, tension and ill will in the community but also it has diverted the Minister's attention from some of the real problems of his administration. The Auditor-General's report shows that his attention has been diverted from the real issues facing the Aboriginal people in Australia today.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister, in his statement, makes no mention of the role of the NAC or its Chairman. I suggest to the Minister, through you, Madam Deputy Speaker, that the reputation of the Chairman of the NAC has been destroyed by this report. The Minister makes no criticism or statement about this. He has come into this House and made a very brief statement on the NAC. That is an insult to the Parliament and it is typical of the Minister's conduct in the administration of this portfolio to act only when he is forced to do so and to avoid debate in this Parliament at all costs. This Parliament has been insulted by the Minister because he makes Press statement after Press statement and does not come into this House. He has not even brought the Government's preferred uniform land rights model to this House because he is afraid to do so. He comes in here today with a very brief statement, hoping we will not notice and that it all will go away. The report tabled by the Minister today is also an indictment of the Aboriginal leadership in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—The honourable member for Melbourne interjects. The Aboriginal leadership stands responsible. The NAC leadership cannot go round saying it wants more and more by way of land rights claims when it has this massive misuse of government and people's funds, as is set out in this report today. The NAC will be condemned by the whole Australian community. The NAC's reputation-
—Do you support land rights, by the way? You are the shadow Minister. What is your policy on land rights?
—I did not interject on the Minister when he spoke, Madam Deputy Speaker.

SPEECH.PARA: I am suggesting to the Minister and the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) that the National Aboriginal Conference's reputation is in tatters. Its credibility must be zero because its actions and its negligence make it harder for those in government and in opposition who are really trying to achieve improvement in the real living standards of Aboriginal people to look at the real needs in health, welfare and housing. Their task is made that much harder by this massive abuse by the National Aboriginal Conference.

The NAC stands condemned for its actions as revealed by this report. I shall briefly refer to some of the matters mentioned in the Auditor-General's report because, whilst the Minister has tabled it, we owe a duty to this House to reveal to the public some of these areas. Let us look at 'Procurement Cash Payments' in the Auditor-General's report. He says:

Deficiencies included the fact that a significant percentage of paid claims and supporting invoices which this Office desired to examine were missing. Four cheque forms had also apparently been taken without authority and fraudulently negotiated.

Then there is the matter of a co-ordinating office being set up in Mexico to facilitate the Conference's participation in the Fourth General Assembly of the World Council of Indigenous People. There is also the question of salaries and members' remuneration. The report states:
. . . the processing of members' remuneration and the payment of allowances were deficient.
Then there is the matter of travel. I quote from the report:
Significant deficiencies were noted in the system and procedures for the processing of payments of travelling allowances.
As to motor vehicles, the report states:
There was significant failure to comply with directions given by the Minister in relation to the purchase of motor vehicles in the 1983-84 year.

I will not take the time of the House unnecessarily but there is a responsibility to reveal this matter in the Parliament. The report refers to procurement cash payments in the attachments. It states that deficiencies included the hire of commercial rental cars without purchase orders being raised. Twenty-six instances were noted during audit test checks. Other examples were an instance of unauthorised Commonwealth car hire, a reimbursement of taxi, bus and airfares without an appropriate approval, and the charter of a plane by a member without approval, which was subsequently approved.
Let us look at the payment of unauthorised expenditure as revealed by the Auditor-General's report on the National Aboriginal Conference. It states:
Several amounts approved for payment did not appear to have been authorised by the terms of the Conference's Charter, Rules and Accounting arrangements.
Let us look at some of these. They included:
Payments to some employees for accumulated flex-time.
Approximately 300 payments in the period July 1983 to April 1984 (almost 10% of total payments) of a salary nature had not been processed as intended . . .
At least 40 payments classified as salary advances were in fact in the nature of small, short-term, interest free loans . . .
22 payments of parking and speeding infringements--
to NAC members-
The payment of travelling allowances to Members' wives totalling $3,150.
This is an indictment of the Minister's administration and of the NAC leadership. I go on:
The hire of a commercial rent-a-car by a member from June 1983 to approximately February 1984 at a total hire cost of $4,200--
that must have been fun-
The hire of a commercial rent-a-car for the Canberra Secretariat-

TALK.START.PARA: —Not as good as John Brown, but getting there.

—Almost as good as the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, as my colleague reminds me. I am reading aspects of the Auditor-General's report on the NAC. I am giving examples of unauthorised expenditure. I was saying that another example is:

SPEECH.PARA: The hire of a commercial rent-a-car for the Canberra Secretariat for an indeterminable length of time although the Secretariat also had the use of Department of Administrative Services cars.
Here is another interesting example for which the NAC leadership must really stand responsible and condemned. It is:
The hire of a bus for Members for a day trip to the snowfields.
The payment for a day tour and lunch for Members' wives.
The payment of membership subscriptions to the TAA 'Flight Deck Club' and Ansett 'Golden Wing Club' for the then Deputy Chairman and 2 staff members.

These are most serious matters. I have read them from the report tabled in Parliament today. I refer briefly to other matters in that report. On salaries and members' remuneration, it states that the accounting arrangements were not complied with in that:
Members' remuneration was sometimes not in accordance with the relevant Remuneration Tribunal Determination.
Other deficiencies in the audit included:
Salary was frequently advanced for other than an approved purpose.
In numerous cases no evidence was sighted on their personnel file of approval for the appointment of officers.
No documentary evidence was sighted that an employee worked overtime for which she was paid.
Frequently no evidence was available on personnel files to confirm dates of resignation.
I could go on. Concerning deficiencies, I conclude by quoting:
Overtime and higher duties allowances were not always paid promptly.

This is a massive indictment, as I have said, of the NAC leadership and of the Minister. It makes it harder for those really trying to achieve real progress in the serious problems, of which there are many, facing the Aboriginal people today. The NAC leadership screams about uniform national land rights. for the leaders to carry on in the way they have, as indicated in this report, shows that they do not have the interests of the Aboriginal people at heart. They have at heart their own interest in feathering their own nest. Their actions unfairly bring the attitude of many non-Aboriginal Australians to one of doubting the seriousness of Aboriginal claims. Further, the actions of the National Aboriginal Conference as shown in this report will make it harder for those trying to achieve progress because non-Aboriginal Australians will say that Aboriginals have not deserved the trust and respect of the community. The NAC itself, by its actions and by its mismanagement and misappropriation of funds, will lead to more divisiveness, more tension and more misunderstanding in the community. The NAC stands condemned, as does the Minister and his administration of his portfolio.
Motion (by Mr Maher) proposed:
That the debate be now adjourned.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Wild Horses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have the wild horses of Queensland and the Northern Territory declared a protected species.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will set aside a National Park for these horses and ensure that killing of feral animals be undertaken in a humane manner with proper legislation and enforcement.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baldwin,Mr Beddall,Mr Lindsay,Mr Mountford and Mrs Sullivan.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and its future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman,Mr Ewen Cameron,Mr Ruddock,Mr Shipton and Mr Staples.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Wild Horses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have the brumby declared a protected species.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House follow the example of President Nixon in the USA by declaring our wild horses protected from industry and indiscriminate slaughter.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baldwin,Mr Beddall,Mr Cross and Mr Gear.

PETITION.TITLE: Koalas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have the koala declared an endangered species and given the proper protection of the Commonwealth.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House declare that the koala may not be exported from this country and that urgent re-vegetation of their habitats be carried out. Your petitioners also humbly pray that Commonwealth Government funds will be made available for research into the disease Chlamydia Psittaci which is killing the koala.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baldwin,Mr Dobie and Mr Langmore.

PETITION.TITLE: Social Security and Repatriation Assets Test Abolition Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Governments failure to act to correct the anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions bring to its notice and due to have effect from the 21 March, 1985 the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners, and calls upon the Australian Democrats to support Senator Messner's bill for the abolition of the Assets Test.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the passage of the Social Security and Repatriation Assets Test Abolition Bill to repeal the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman and Mr Drummond.

PETITION.TITLE: Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we are greatly concerned with the extent to which serious crime including murder, major drug financing and massive tax frauds have penetrated into the highest levels of Australian society as shown by the investigations of various Royal Commissioners and in particular by Mr Frank Costigan Q.C.

That we are concerned that the National Crime Authority has too many restrictions and possible lines of veto placed upon it for it to be an effective successor to the Costigan Enquiry and that this will allow major criminals to avoid prosecution.

And your petitioners humbly pray that the Federal Government negotiate urgently with the Victorian Government on the reactivation of the Costigan Commission and to extend its term to at least the 31st March, 1985 and also to provide the Costigan Commission with whatever resources it may need to successfully conclude its investigations into organised crime in Australia. Further we believe that the issue of organised crime in Australia is so important that the Parliament should not be dissolved until at least the interim Costigan Report has been received and fully debated in both Houses of the Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Hawke Government be called upon to remove the unjust and cruel Assets Test;
That the Assets Test will mean the sale of homes, of cars, and treasured possessions which have been accumulated over many years of hard work and saving;
That the introduction of the Government's grab for the assets of old people is condemned as un-Australian;
That the Government is requested to reconsider the Assets Test.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully requests the Government to introduce laws to:
(1) Prevent the importation and sale of hard core pornography and grossly obscene publications,
(2) Register imported pornographic video tapes for non-commercial use with the Film Censorship Board and require the Censor to more appropriately reflect responsible community attitudes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Life and Democratic Institutions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the loyal citizens of Australia firmly express our strong opposition to any proposals to remove or undermine the importance of the place of God and/or the Queen in our national life, and democratic institutions.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That the Parliament assembled reaffirm our nation's total dependence on God the Creator in accordance with our Australian Constitution, which commences with the words ''Humbly relying on the blessing of Almighty God'', and the Standing Orders of both the Senate and the House of Representatives which prescribe that Parliament each day shall open with a special prayer to Almighty God and the Lord's Prayer.
We also call on the Parliament assembled to re-affirm our genuine loyalty to our Head of State, the Queen of Australia, Elizabeth II-'God save the Queen'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Institute of Tertiary Education Proposal
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned and in particular the Student Association of the Canberra School of Art respectfully showeth:

That we, in particular the Students of the Canberra School of Art, firmly express our strong opposition to the haste with which the National Institute of Tertiary Education proposal has been assembled. We the undersigned, request time to examine the proposal and an opportunity to discuss the ramification thereof.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Entitlements of De Facto Spouses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are concerned that action by the Government to:
(a) extend entitlements and allowances to de facto relationships as outlined in the August Budget
(b) to granting of overseas travel entitlements to other than spouses of Federal members of Parliament
(c) failure of the Government to prevent the granting of privileges and travel allowances of homosexual partners of members of the A.B.C.
has imposed on the Australian community a moral standard fundamentally opposed to the principles of the Christian Church and the majority of the non Christian community.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should take immediate action to ensure that these allowances and privileges are withdrawn and that the Government should do all in its power to consolidate the position of the traditional family unit in the Australian community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the right honourable the Speaker and the honourable members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. We are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. We know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. We recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. We are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will propose and pass a motion that ''existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to take appropriate steps in the wake of the recent depreciation of the Australian dollar.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time today the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) treated us to a veritable avalanche of economic statistics. We were given retail sales figures, unemployment figures, inflation figures, capital investment figures and profit level figures. We had figures adjusted for Queensland, we had seasonally adjusted figures, we had every conceivable economic statistic under the sun bar one that is very relevant to every man, woman and child in Australia at present. That is the statistic that tells us that, since November 1984, there has been a cumulative decline of 21.6 per cent in the value of the Australian dollar against the trade weighted index. It is the statistic that tells us that since the same date there has been a cumulative decline of 22.6 per cent in the value of the Australian dollar against the United States dollar. The Prime Minister, in all his rantings and ravings and hectoring and lecturing and moralising at Question Time today, could not bring himself to tell us about the one statistic I have just quoted. In other words, the world's greatest Treasurer has given us the world's weakest dollar.
—You have given us that.

—The Treasurer (Mr Keating) does not like to be reminded of this. He is a little sensitive about it. Not only has the world's greatest Treasurer given us the world's weakest dollar, not only does the Prime Minister cut and run in the face of the unpalatable statistics, not only is the Prime Minister the most selective statistic quoter that this Parliament has seen for many years, but also, even worse than that, the Prime Minister leads a government which is unable to address in a proper manner the consequences of the recent depreciation of the Australian dollar.

SPEECH.PARA: If ever the Australian community has witnessed a devaluation in a Prime Minister, they saw it last week. On three separate occasions the Prime Minister went public and tried to tell the Australian people what the Government was going to do in the wake of the devaluation of the dollar. He grants an exclusive interview to Max Walsh on the National program. He runs hot and strong about the productivity case. The next day Simon Crean rings him up and says: 'Hey, Bob, what is all this nonsense about not giving us past productivity?' The Prime Minister cuts and runs and says: 'Maybe at some time in the future we will trade off the price effects of devaluation against a future productivity case'. He then has a Press conference and says that there is no difference of opinion between himself and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. He further confuses the issue and leaves it hanging in the air.

He then goes to Western Australia and waxes lyrical before a Western Australian audience about the marvellous benefits of devaluation. The Prime Minister says that 100,000 manufacturing jobs can be created. I see the Treasurer nodding his head. I tell the Treasurer that that reminds honourable members on this side of the House of that famous, that memorable, that never-to-be-forgotten response of the former Labor Treasurer, Jim Cairns, after he had been arguing that the purpose of running an expansionary monetary policy was to reduce unemployment. He was asked by the former member for Wakefield, Bert Kelly: 'If that is the case, Treasurer, why do you not turn the handle a bit faster and get rid of unemployment altogether?'

If the Treasurer and the Prime Minister think they are talking economic sense in the vein that the Prime Minister was using last Friday, I may well ask the Prime Minister and the Treasurer why they do not devalue the dollar a bit further and get rid of unemployment altogether.

We should not have the sort of nonsense the Treasurer is going on with and the sort of nonsense the Prime Minister went on with while the Treasurer was in Paris talking to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. I am not criticising the Treasurer for doing that because, frankly, I think the Treasurer of Australia ought to be spending a bit of time overseas at the moment, reassuring international investors that the leadership of the Prime Minister is not quite as devalued as they imagined it to be. We should not have the sort of economic cant, humbug and nonsense that the Prime Minister was going on with last week. He made three attempts and he still did not get it right. He ran up to it all right. He analysed the problem all right. He said: 'If we have a devaluation we get benefits from it, and we have to be careful that we do not lose all those benefits'. But having analysed the problem, having walked up to it and boldly stated the problem, the Prime Minister then ran away from it.

The fact is that a depreciation of our currency is not costless. It bears upon all sections of the Australian community. It represents, perhaps temporarily, but that depends upon future international assessments of the strength of the Australian economy, a depreciation of the national assets of this country. But it does involve some advantages. Those advantages are principally to be found in the competitive gains it affords to our exporters and to our import competing industries. In a sense, a devaluation of the Australian dollar acts as a readjustment of the competitive position of those industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do tell.

—The Treasurer says: 'Do tell'. After the void in economic logic through the Treasurer's absence and the Prime Minister's meanderings over the last few months, the Australian people are entitled to some kind of explanation. This Treasurer has copped out on explanations about the value of the Australian dollar. It is all right for a Treasurer to say 'I will not talk about the value of the Australian dollar', when we have an administered exchange rate, when the Treasurer is actually fixing the market value of the Australian dollar; but when we have a floating exchange rate it is an absolute cop out for the Treasurer to run to silence and say absolutely nothing. It is a cop out for him to say: 'I cannot talk about the Australian dollar because, if I do, it will be absolutely improper'. That is a phoney excuse. It is a cop out, and it is an example of the Treasurer running from his responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: Those gains to our import competing industries and our export industries will be retained only if the right policies are followed consequent upon the depreciation when it takes place. If the wrong policies are followed those gains will not be retained and, once again, we will face a further depreciation of our currency. If the gains to our import competing industries and our export industries are to be retained, it is imperative that those industries not pay the additional cost burden of full indexation of their employee's wages. Unpopular though that may be to many honourable members on the other side of the House and to many people in the trade union movement, if there is a full compensation through the wage indexation system the comparative gains of those industries will be lost. The depreciation has restored their competitive position. It has given them a second chance, a breathing space. The economic challenge for this Government is to make sure that that breathing space is not squandered and that that second chance is grabbed hold of. If the Government stands by and allows a full indexation of wages to take place, through the prices and incomes accord, that competitive gain will be lost.

What did we hear from the Prime Minister last week and again today? It was implicit in the way in which he dodged the question I asked him about company profitability. It is all right to rant and rave about profitability levels over the last couple of years. The truth is that, if we have a future increase in wages on the basis of past productivity which is what Simon Crean wants and what the Prime Minister was browbeaten into agreeing to last week, we will erode the present level of company profitability and, therefore, interfere with employment levels. If there is not an equal sharing of the burdens of depreciation on all sectors of the Australian community, the competitive gain to our industries will be lost.

The Prime Minister and the Australian Labor Party seem to have some idea that the prices and incomes accord represents a monumental sacrifice by the trade union movement in the interests of economic recovery. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer are always lecturing us about the great contribution the prices and incomes accord has made to economic recovery in Australia. We are always being told that the drop in the inflation rate is due to the prices and incomes accord. We were told that again today. The truth is that the principal reason for the drop in the inflation rate over the last couple of years was the 9 per cent reduction in real wages produced by the wages pause, which was opposed by the ACTU and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), who was then Leader of the Opposition, and by many people in the Opposition at that time. It was due also to the depressing effect of an economic recession on price competition and price levels in Australia.

It is an absolute historic and economic untruth for the Treasurer and the Prime Minister to keep saying that the reduction in the inflation rate that occurred through 1983 was due to the prices and incomes accord. The prices and incomes accord did not come into operation until September or October of 1983. How on earth could it have had an impact on inflation rates in the June and September quarters of 1983? It is one of the great myths that has been peddled around by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer about the contribution of the prices and incomes accord to the reduction in our inflation rate. So, far from the prices and incomes accord representing a sacrifice by the trade union movement of this country, the truth really is that trade unionists in this country would not have obtained in the open market place in 1983 the sort of wage increases that have been given to them under the prices and incomes accord. It is no wonder that Bill Kelty said to the socialist forum at the beginning of this year that the Australian trade union movement is the luckiest in the world because it has got the prices and incomes accord.

There is a very clear obligation resting on this Government, in a climate where business-both domestic and international-perceptions of this Government have changed dramatically. Our dollar has gone down for a combination of reasons. Let me say, in fairness, that not all of those reasons are within the control of this Government. I do not hold this Government responsible for the decline in international commodity prices which have had an adverse effect on our dollar. This Government is not responsible for the fact that the United States dollar is at record levels, but this Government and this Prime Minister in particular are responsible for the MX fiasco. The MX missile fiasco has had a catastrophic effect on international financial perceptions of this country.

This Government and this Treasurer are also responsible for a series of economic decisions over the last few months that have added, in a cumulative way, to the growing doubts and growing misperceptions of international and domestic financial markets about Australia. Last week the Prime Minister had the nerve and the gall and the cheek to say that financial markets in Australia had been behaving in an irrational manner. Madam Deputy Speaker, I put it to you that it is the Prime Minister who has behaved in an irrational manner about financial markets. After all, it was the Prime Minister and the Treasurer who wilfully and wantonly and in a most deceitful manner promised the Australian people lower interest rates at the time of the last election campaign. The Treasurer crawls and slinks in here and now he tries to say that he was merely echoing what people in the financial markets were saying. He said: 'Oh, it was not really Paul Keating. I was really repeating what the people in the financial markets are saying. You know they are very impressive. Every time they say something I have a pavlovian instinct to echo, on interest rates, precisely what they say'. The fact is that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer both promised the Australian people that there would be lower interest rates before the last election. They have been caught out. They have been found to have misled the Australian people on the question of interest rates. No wonder we have a devalued Prime Minister; no wonder we have changing perceptions about economic management in Australia; and no wonder we have declining international financial confidence.

But that is of the past. What is more important is the current and future reaction of the Australian Government to the depreciation of our dollar. There are two things that the Government must do: Firstly, it must make it perfectly clear that it will argue at the next national wage case for a full discounting of the wage indexation process for the consumer price index effects of the depreciation, and secondly, it must make it perfectly clear that it will argue strenuously in any productivity hearing this year, or indeed next year, against any situation where past productivity gains are to be reflected in future wage increases, because if that occurs we will have an erosion of the profit share and we will have a resumption of the increase in levels of unemployment. Last week the Prime Minister addressed the problem, but he completely ducked the answer. We now have the Treasurer back in Australia. We welcome him back. We wait with keen anticipation for the Treasurer to tell the Australian people right now what the right response is to the depreciation of the Australian dollar and to tell us the things that the Prime Minister, through his weakness and failure, so clearly was unable to tell us on three separate occasions last week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have all these crocodile tears about inflation from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who is worried about the inflation portents of a decline in the value of the Australian dollar when this Government has succeeded in getting inflation down to 5 per cent and when he left us a legacy of just on 12 per cent. So Mr 12 Per Cent here, who presided over the collapse of the Australian economy and record post-war inflation is now terribly worried about the fact that we might lift inflation above 5 per cent. He is horrified, aggrieved and shocked at the portents for the Australian economy if inflation should move over 5 per cent, but he was quite happy to stand up here for two years and defend 11 per cent and 12 per cent inflation figures when he was in government. In opposition, we talked about the disastrous state of Australian competitiveness-the fact that we were being wiped out in markets all around the world, with inflation rates of 11 per cent and 12 per cent. But it took this Government, this Government's policies and the prices and incomes accord to get inflation down from 11 1/2 per cent, which we inherited, to 5 per cent. But now he is terribly worried about the fact that it might move over 5 per cent again. All I say to him is: 'Do not worry about it. We will worry about it. We have got the job of worrying about it and we will concern ourselves about the inflationary portent of these particular changes'.

SPEECH.PARA: But we have this extravagant language of the motion, 'The failure of the Government to take appropriate steps', as if when there is a change in the market situation the Government has to race out straight away and fix it. There is this sort of crazy notion that the Government responds a minute after things happen to get things fixed. The next national wage case which the honourable member for Bennelong has been bleating about is not till six months away. We do not know where the trade weight will settle down in the medium term. Yet we have this crazy, extravagant language about how we have to race in now and take appropriate steps to fix inflation, after he left us 12 per cent. You can imagine just how impressed I am with that little performance, Madam Deputy Speaker. At least I will say this for him: He did at least have the decency to say that the correction in the Australian dollar will improve the competitiveness of the Australian economy, which is more than the other buffoons behind him even understand. They think the Australian dollar is some sort of index of economic virility. If we do not have 85c, or whatever it is, the currency is no good. That is the sort of simplistic nonsense that is in their minds. At least he disabused some of his own colleagues of that.

Let me just make this point, and it is one of the most important points: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition speaks as though, all things being equal, under his policies he could deliver some adjustment in respect of the devaluation, which would maintain inflation at the level this Government has secured it at. Let me say this to him first and foremost: Under his policies we would have already had the increase that he fears; we would have had the increase in 1984. Is he suggesting that through a year of massive growth, of massive pickup in profits, he would have had a no increase in award wage outcome like we had? He would not have had a chance. He would have had increases in wages in 1984 under his policies, more than the ones he is now saying he fears. So he should not go talking about what we have to adjust to keep inflation at 5 per cent. In the first place, he would not have got it there and even if he had got near it, he would not have been able to hold it in 1984 because, in the classic circumstance, in the classic mode of this economy, in a period of strong growth and a lift in profits, wages would have lifted. So he cannot come to us. We have had two years of the best back to back wage restraint in decades. That is why we have inflation at 5 per cent, and we will have the same in 1985.

This Government understands that the depreciation presents a challenge and as a responsible government we will address it, but we will do what is feasible. We will not be responding to some theoretically foolish proposition the Opposition might mount about what it would do because when it was in government it could secure no wage outcome at all.

When the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) was Minister for Industrial Relations, he presided over the biggest post-war blowout in wages that we have seen. That is why the current account deficit is substantially the way it is. That is why Australia's loss of competitiveness is the way it is. The competitiveness of the Australian economy was revealed when the economy became taut once more under some sort of growth situation. Before we saw the growth attach itself to the economy, it was not evident what degree of damage had been done by the wage explosion presided over by these two vandals. Now they come in and tell us how to manage the economy and keep wages under control. They were never able to secure any wage outcome. Under the industrial relations policy that they now support they would now be able to go to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and say that they wanted to discount wages because there would be no commission; there would be no centralised wage system.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we wouldn't.

—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has confirmed that he has no solution. If that is the case, why does he think that in some deregulated labour market he can produce a better outcome than the result that we produced in 1984?
—Far better.
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition says that he could do better than our no wage increase in 1984.
—A lot better than you.
—We have had no increase for a year.
—Order! Both gentleman at the table will cease talking across the table.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, it is a feature of these matters of public importance that this clown from Tasmania sits there and interjects right through the debate. He should be sitting in his own seat.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order on this 60c in the dollar Treasurer for always making statements reflecting on Tasmania and Tasmanians. I ask him to withdraw.
—That is no point of order. You may ask him to withdraw.
—I will withdraw if he desists from interjecting.
—The honourable member for Denison is interjecting continually. He is interjecting from the table which is outside his seat.
—I am on duty.
—You are on duty; I beg your pardon. But will you please cease interjecting?

—The fact is that under the coalition's policy it could secure no wage outcome at all. It does not believe in centralised wage fixing. It would abolish the Commission. It could seek no discounting, and yet it has this sort of view that in some deregulated situation some adjustment in wages would not occur. What is the evidence for that? What was the history in 1981-82 of deregulation? We saw a 17 1/2 per cent increase in wages in 1981-82, and we would see it again.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition talks about wages drift. Who gives wages drift? It is not the Government; it is not the Arbitration Commission; it is the employers who provide wages drift. It is employers who pay wages drift. Why does the Opposition think they would not pay it now? Why does it think that, if the Arbitration Commission did not exist, if centralised wage fixing did not exist and the prices and incomes accord did not exist, we would not see a movement in wages? Of course we would see a movement in wages. The Opposition has a crazy assumption that in some deregulated nirvana situation there would be no increase in wages. How can those fools over there ever believe that they would get no increase in award wages for a year, as we have done, with such strong conditions in the economy? We had a 2.6 per cent increase in award wages in the year to April. The previous Government had an increase of 17.6 per cent in the year 1981-82. That is its record. Opposition members do not have a leg to stand on, and yet they come in here and talk about how we ought to be taking steps.

We had the courage to give Australia the flexible policy option of the floating exchange rate-something that the coalition Government did not have the courage to do. That change in the value of the dollar is affecting for the better the competitiveness of this country. That will mean that our export industries can compete in the world again; their competitiveness will be enhanced. It will mean that our import competing industries will recover, as they should. Why were they in this position? It was because of the mismanagement of policies with relation to competitiveness. They were not competitive. That is the reason why they were in that position. That is the value of seeing a competitive adjustment in Australia's trading position. It is a ridiculous notion that the coalition has any answers to competitiveness; the coalition's policies were the root cause of the particular troubles in terms of competitiveness. The reason was that it was running an overvalued currency. It was running an overvalued dollar for years. Why was that? It was because the Treasury and the Reserve Bank of Australia ran it for the coalition. Why was that? It was because they did not believe that the former Government had a credible anti-inflation policy. They took the policy out of the previous Government's hands and ran an overvalued exchange rate because the former Treasurer blew the money supply targets for five years in a row.

The previous government had no fiscal discipline and no incomes policy. Today the former Treasurer even admitted again to the Prime Minister that he said in a television program last year: 'The major failing of the Fraser Government was that we had no incomes policy'. He has repeated it and he confirms it again with a nod. The previous government had no incomes policy. It had no decent monetary policy. The Reserve Bank and the Treasury said: 'OK, at least we will do something for Australia. We can overvalue the exchange rate and keep some sort of anti-inflation discipline on the economy'. But in so doing, by that distortion in the policy mix, it rendered uncompetitive our export industries and our import competing industries. This Government has provided a mechanism to change that.

Let me put to rest this bunkum that we cannot have deregulated financial markets beside a so-called regulated wage market. That is saying that, if we have a regulated wage market, we should continue with the constipation of financial and monetary markets. I reject that absolutely. This Government has taken the view that we should get the best from financial markets-the maximum flexibility in financial markets-and at the same time the maximum result from the labour market. There can be no free market for labour in the country. The labour market is not organised to provide a free market. We did not see wage increases being granted to the strongest industries, the ones with the greatest capacity to pay; they were granted to the strongest unions, regardless of industry's capacity to pay. This labour market cannot function and is not organised as a market; it cannot operate as a free market.

It is a simplistic notion that deregulated labour markets and deregulated financial markets go hand in hand. We cannot have deregulated financial markets and a centralised wage system. Who could possibly argue that a deregulated labour market last year or in 1983-84 would have provided a better outcome than this Government secured with no increase in award wages for a year? How could that sort of result possibly be delivered in a deregulated environment, if that could be provided? How could we get a deregulated market? How would we smash the 300-odd unions in Australia and the industrial organisational base of Australia so as to get work place negotiation, industry unions or any of the other things which would have to be part and parcel of some flexibility in the labour market? It cannot be done. What happens in our labour market is that the prizes go to the strong unions, not to the strong industries or on any evaluation of capacity to pay. They go to the people with the muscle. That sort of situation is dealt with in the way that this Government has chosen to deal with it, that is, through a centralised system by an agreed basis between the trade union movement and the Government. That is why it is totally harmonious and totally consistent to have the best from deregulated financial markets with the kind of incomes policy this Government has. It is an absolute furphy for anybody to argue--

TALK.START.PARA: —But you have to discount then, do you?
—What would he know about it? He is just a failed lawyer.
—Order! Will the honourable member cease interjecting?
—Why does he not keep quiet for a moment?

—On a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker. Is it really consistent with proper standards of debate for the Treasurer to use these constantly personal denigratory expressions such as 'failed lawyer' to my colleague?
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat.
—Will he just let me finish my point, please?

—Order! The Treasurer will remain silent for a moment. The honourable member for Menzies will cease interjecting while the Treasurer is speaking. It is the intention of the Chair for the person who has the call from the Chair to be heard. The Chair does not need any instruction from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.
—What about discounting?
—I warn the honourable member for Menzies. If he interjects again, I will name him.
—He is an ignorant Establishment pig, Madam Deputy Speaker.
—Order! The Treasurer will withdraw that remark.
—I will withdraw it if he will stop interjecting.
—I did not ask you to withdraw.
—He should just stop interjecting and shut up for five minutes.
—Order! The Chair asks for a withdrawal.
—I did not ask him to withdraw.
—Will you please resume your seat. There is no point of order.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, it is entirely consistent to get the best from financial markets in a deregulated mode by addressing the structural problems of the Australian labour market with an incomes policy. It is a complete furphy for anybody to argue that there is some dichotomy or some competitive position between deregulated financial markets and regulated financial markets. I say to the Opposition that it is responsible for Australia's loss of competitiveness. We have put the instruments in place to regain it. The Government, like any sensible government, will approach the problems which may arise from a change in the parity of our currency with other currencies within the context of the incomes policies which we have set up for that purpose. We reject absolutely the proposition mounted by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition this afternoon.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The contribution by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to this afternoon's debate is summed up by the last exchange, which was particularly unpleasant. It is always the answer of those who resort-
—Order! The Treasurer withdrew the remark. It will not be commented on.
—It was probably the best part of his speech.

—It probably was the best part of this speech. I thank the honourable member for Menzies. As I was saying, those who resort to talking about matters that do not necessarily relate directly to the debate in trying to answer questions that are raised about matters of public importance really give away the fact that they are not arguing the central issues we are trying to discuss. The question that is really raised by this debate is what is happening with the fall in the Australian dollar. When members of the public see the Australian dollar fall they know there is a reason for it. The reason we have seen for it in Australia is the perception of the lack of quality of the leadership and of the economic management this Government is giving. One has only to look at some of the things that are being said by economic commentators about what is happening. There are some benefits in the devaluation of the dollar. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has pointed those out. One is that our export competing industries and those industries within Australia that compete with importing industries get a comparative advantage. If we want to capitalise on that, the essence of the argument is that we should be looking to discounting the consumer price index effects of the devaluation at the next national wage case. The Treasurer says that the national wage case is six months away. However, we are talking about the intervening period and the perception by the international monetary markets of the value of the Australian dollar. As early as 15 February 1985 an article appeared in the Australian Financial Review which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . when the balance of payments figures show that if anything there is a strong case for real wage reductions across the board.

For this is what the current account deficit, the growing debt-servicing burden, and the decline of the dollar together mean-the capacity of the Australian economy to maintain the present level of living standards, let alone wage increases, is declining, not increasing.

That is the essence of the argument. That is what the housewives understand. They know what is going on. If we completely ignore the problems that are caused by the devaluation of the dollar and we do not capitalise on the advantages it gives us, we will find that the ordinary people in this community, as well as those in the international financial markets, will lose all faith in this Government. The broad test for this Government is whether it can seize the issue, whether it can get to the nub of the issue, which is to give to Australia the benefits that we can accrue by discounting, at the national wage case hearing, the consumer price index increases because of the devaluation of the dollar. It is no good saying that the national wage case is six months away. We have to let people know now. People want to know now. That is what is important.

The Far Eastern Economic Review is a magazine that is read throughout East Asia. The Ferris report of the National Export Marketing Strategy Panel indicates to us that that is the direction in which we ought to be going. We ought to be trying to capitalise on those markets. We have been told by many a commentator that East Asia is the quickest and fastest growing economic area in our region, yet are we participating in it? The answer probably is that we are not doing so to the best of our capacity. We now have the opportunity to do so. But what has happened? We had the MX missile debacle. We have had other debacles. I show the House the front page of the 7 March edition of the Far Eastern Economic Review. What does it have on it? It has Tasmania right at the top of the page as Australia is upside down. The caption reads: 'STOP THE WORLD, WE WANT TO GET OFF'. The reason that is so is that the magazine perceived, when discussing the MX missile issue that Australia and, to a large extent, New Zealand were blinkered in their approach, that they wanted to ignore completely the reality of the situation in the region in which we find ourselves. The 7 March edition of the Far Eastern Economic Review adds to the perception in a region where we ought to be working hard and trying to get financial people involved in our economy that this Government is not in control. That is exactly what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said.

We have a Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who is ridden with factions. He is unsettled by them. He is unable to give the direction in which he wants to go because he is overly concerned that the factions within the Labor Party will not go along with what he wants to do with regard to depreciating the next CPI national wage case adjustments. Of course, the Australian Council of Trade Unions also does not want to be involved in going along that route. That is very unfortunate for Australia because, if we do not capitalise on the very good opportunity we now have, States such as Tasmania-a State which has, ever since Federation, shown an export credit rather than a deficit and been a net exporter for the nation-will lose the advantages which our economy could have.

Whenever the Treasurer comes into the chamber-the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) raised this point-he always seems to ridicule Tasmanians. That is unfortunate because the Government will not do any good in Tasmania until it starts to realise the benefits that Tasmania brings to the economy of this nation. I hope that in future the Treasurer will take more care as to how he addresses debates that are so important to this country. I shall quote from the editorial of the Canberra Times of 12 April 1985. The appearance by the Prime Minister on the National television program-there was another appearance in Western Australia-was somewhat lacking in substance. It has been perceived by most commentators as evidence of the fact that we still do not know where we are going. Did the Prime Minister's appearance allay any fears? The answer clearly is no. Let us look at the overall question. The Canberra Times editorial states:

. . . the most important cause of the depreciation has been the sudden deterioration in expectations about the future behaviour of the currency. Individual causes of the deterioration in perceptions are a familiar litany-the Government's retreat on the matter of the MX missile--
that is evidenced, as I have just shown, by the Far Eastern Economic Review-
the Parliamentary Labor Party's refusal to countenance the restoration of tertiary-education fees . . .

Let me stop here and take that point. The night before the tertiary education fees debate the honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan)-a left wing member-read to us in the House from the platform of the Australian Labor Party telegraphing his punches to his colleagues regarding what he was going to do the next morning in the Caucus room. When that sort of activity is seen by the broader community it gives rise to the fears that this Government does not know where it is going. We all agree that when the Government came to office it had a massive 20.3 per cent surge in income. It has not capitalised on it. It has frittered it away. Now the dollar has done something the Government never expected it to do. It now does not know what to do. That is just not good enough. What are the other causes of the deterioration in perceptions as mentioned in the article in the Canberra Times? One is the abandonment of monetary targets. I remember that some time ago the Treasurer said: 'Do not worry about it. I have it under control'. He said that in this very House. That is what he said again today. He said: 'Do not worry about it. I will get to it in good time'. There may not be time for Australia if we continue along this path. What are some of the other causes of the deterioration in perceptions? The article continues:
. . . and the Australian Council of Trade Unions' refusal to consider discounting for depreciation in the wage-indexation procedures.

As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition so aptly said, Simon Crean rang up the day after the Prime Minister appeared on the National and said: 'Wait. You cannot do that to us. We are the ones who are keeping you in power. Remember, we helped you write your Budget'. What is to happen this time? Who is running this country? Is it to be Simon Crean, the de facto head of the ACTU, or is it to be the Prime Minister? When the Prime Minister comes into the chamber he speaks volumes to his left wing back bench to try to appease its members. He is spending all his time trying to marry the disparate factions within the Labor Party and ignoring the broader issues of what ought to be his task in running this country. The article in the Canberra Time finally states:
Collectively they add up to the perception--
perception is the key word; that is what we are talking about; let us know now what the Government is going to do-
that the Cabinet will not be able to maintain control of moderate economic policies, but will lose control to a militant caucus with detremental inflationary effects and further depreciation.
That says it all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Moscow corner.
—Moscow corner. I quote from the 12 April edition of the Sydney Morning Herald, a journal respected in most quarters. The editorial states:

SPEECH.PARA: This 'trust me' and 'wait and see' approach is hardly ideal from the public's viewpoint and might be quite unsatisfactory to a gloomy foreign exchange market . . .

That really encapsulates the problem. The Government does not know what it is doing and it does not know where to go. If it does not let us know whether it intends to allow for the effect of depreciation at the next national wage case and if it does not indicate now that any past productivity gain will not be included in full wage increases, this country's export industry will not benefit at all from the effects of depreciation. This, as we all know, is the direction in which this country ought to be going. It ought to be concentrating all its efforts on being much more competitive in a region of the world where we have the opportunity to contribute to a large extent not only to stability but also to an overall increase in our living standards.

When something like this occurs, what must all those involved in industries throughout South East Asia think when they see that Australia has turned itself upside down? They say: 'Ah, Australia stop the world we want to get off'. Somebody ought to say to the ACTU: 'Maybe you ought to get off and let the rest of us get on with the job'. If we do not get on with the job, good States like Tasmania-I have to defend Tasmania because it is always being attacked-will lose the advantages.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once more, it seems that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), in proposing and speaking to a matter of public importance in the House this afternoon, has displayed his regular mathematical gymnastics and some of his associated illogicality. To be fair to him, he is slowly beginning to get his propensity for illogical analysis under control. Informed sources have attested to the fact that he has come to the conclusion that if both a horse and a table have four legs, there must be a very definite connection. His essential difficulty now is to establish the exact nature of this connection. Given the fact that he and his Party will have a long time in opposition I am sure he will eventually get it right.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that this afternoon there has not been a contribution to the debate on this matter of public importance from the National Party of Australia. That intrigues me to some extent. Having read today's edition of the Australian Financial Review, I am sure that many members of the National Party in this chamber would be somewhat embarrassed to contribute to this debate. One headline in the paper stated: 'Dollar's fall softens farm income drop'. This is very good news for the rural sector. It indicates that there will be a record level of farm export earning in 1984-85. There will be an increase of 9 per cent on the earnings of the previous financial year. The level of depreciation has added a projected $530m to rural Australia's net value of production, a not insignificant amount or benefit from the effect of devaluation. Taking into account the expected decline in farm income in Australia this year, which was predicted to be 17 per cent, the depreciating dollar has in fact reduced this rate of decline to 14 per cent. The basic reason for such a decline is not related at all to the economic performance of Australia but is a reflection of the market forces in world-wide commodity prices, as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition admitted during the course of his remarks.

I suggest that the record speaks for itself. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) enunciated some of the points on which we differ quite sharply from our conservative predecessors. We have gone from double digit inflation under the Deputy Leader's stewardship as Treasurer to a level commensurate with that of our Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development trading partners. I am speaking of the previous Treasurer and the previous Government who talked about their 'Fight inflation first policy'. From skyrocketing unemployment, which was out of control at a level of 11 or 12 per cent, we have reduced the level considerably to a more acceptable figure of around 8.8 per cent. From negative economic growth, for the first time in 30 years, we have achieved a continuing, strong rate of economic growth. The previous Government said: 'Let us abandon a centralised wage fixation system; it does not work'. What did we have then? We had a wages explosion, as the Treasurer indicated in the debate today, approaching an annual rate of increase of 17 per cent. We now have a more responsible wages policy. We have an incomes policy that is embodied in the prices and incomes accord. A week ago, we saw the first rise in 12 months in wages in Australia of 2.6 per cent. Another sharp contrast between the Government of which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was a senior member and our Government may be seen as its confrontationist approach versus our approach of consensus. We went from a high level of industrial disputation, encouraged by the sort of Darwinian approach of survival of the fittest in the industrial jungle, to the lowest level of industrial disputation since 1968.

During Question Time today, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made a number of comments about the effects of the depreciation of the dollar. One of the points that he made was that the depreciation gives the Government an opportunity to correct current account balance problems as well as to assist in domestic job creation. I was pleased to see that the Opposition speakers referred to some of those points during their contribution to the debate today. At least they mentioned them even if they did not agree with the Prime Minister's assessment.

The framework of the accord allows us to adjust responsibly to changing circumstances as opposed to the wage spiral that characterised the period under the previous Government-the Fraser Government-in which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition served as Treasurer in 1981-82 during that incredible wage spiral period. The only approach available to the Fraser Government at that time was the hastily conceived and politically motivated wage freeze. The Opposition has criticised the accord in this chamber on countless occasions. The reason for that criticism is a very simple one. The Opposition has never had an incomes policy. From comments made today by Opposition speakers, I feel certain that it does not have an incomes policy that is least comparable with, if not better than, the accord which has operated so successfully.

I turn to some of the positive benefits of devaluation to the rural sector that I mentioned earlier. I referred to the article in today's edition of the Australian Financial Review. I now refer to some of the specific principal commodities that were mentioned in that article. In the case of wheat, more than half of the rise in the gross value of rural production in 1984-85 of $295m has been because of the depreciation of the Australian dollar. In the case of sugar, notwithstanding the problems of finding markets for our troubled sugar industry, the devaluation will result in an injection of an additional $5m in 1985-86, despite a fall in production. With respect to the important Australian wool industry, the Australian Wool Corporation has a stockpile of 300,000 bales of wool. The devaluation of the dollar will help at wool auctions to the tune of a price increase of 45c per kilogram of clean wool. In other words, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics has suggested that $60m will be added to the gross value of wool production in 1984-85.

I now turn to the beef industry. The average sale yard prices will increase by 10 per cent this year. This has been suggested by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. A further rise of 11 per cent is predicted for 1985-86, bringing the gross value of beef exports next financial year to more than $1,266m. In other words, given that rural exports contribute to nearly 50 per cent of total export income for Australia, the depreciated dollar will assist in the process of continuing economic improvement under this Government.

I suggest that it can be assumed that the Opposition's approach is to have government intervention in the economy. Is this what it means by 'appropriate steps'? I believe that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is on record for congratulating the Government for the courageous step it took in December 1983 in floating the Australian dollar. I suggest to the Opposition that it cannot have things both ways. We can either float the dollar or not float it. If we float it, we cannot have the sort of government intervention in the economy as was suggested by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

In the context of the discussions that have taken place in the dairy industry, it is interesting to note that the Executive Director of the Dairy Farmers Federation, Clay Manners, was reported as saying recently:
The devaluation will have a greater impact on the Dairy Industry than the Kerin Plan.

Despite all the recent controversy about the Kerin plan for the dairy industry, we have an industry spokesman commenting in a very positive way, recognising that the benefits of devaluation may help with the surplus of Australian manufactured milk products on the international market. At least there is a recognition within primary industry of the importance of the depreciated dollar. Hence, my comment this afternoon that I am totally amazed that the National Party, the so-called agrarian socialists in this chamber, has not been prepared to make a contribution. It has been prepared to let its coalition partners take all the running in this debate, yet clearly its so-called rural constituency would benefit from devaluation. Once more, the Opposition has demonstrated its extraordinary inability to learn from the lessons of its past economic mismanagement. This matter of public importance is a total sham, and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition knows it.

The National Party must be embarrassed by its submission for debate this afternoon. Although, to be fair, while in coalition government it was obviously happy to see its political bedfellows govern with a consistently overvalued dollar, that was a poor substitute indeed for any responsible monetary and/or fiscal alternatives for spiralling inflation. The result was reflected in the international uncompetitiveness for exporters, particularly in the mining and primary industry sectors.

The Hawke Government is not prepared at all to pull the economic wool over the eyes of Australians or, indeed, the world. The problem with the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is his Gillies-like similarity to Ronnie Corbett. When Ronnie comes on television he likes to think that there are lots of people watching and having a laugh. On the other hand, the honourable member for Bennelong is hoping that there are only a few people looking at him, when he is being funny, and hoping they will not laugh too much.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Keating, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Banks (Shareholding) Act 1972 in order to facilitate the establishment of new banks in Australia as well as to improve the ongoing administration of the Act. A Banks (Shareholdings) Amendment Bill 1984 was introduced into the previous Parliament but had not been passed when Parliament was dissolved for the December 1984 election. The current Bill incorporates the amendments from the 1984 Bill and also makes some additional amendments to facilitate the ongoing administration of the Act.
