TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Bill presently before the House is a constructive move by the Government to approach and remedy the extremely serious problems of land degradation which confront our nation, a nation which is so reliant on the produce from our soil. There is absolutely no doubt about the seriousness of the problem. Our soils exist in a finely balanced state, and it is our responsibility to care for and nurture these limited resources for they do not exist in an infinite supply.

SPEECH.PARA: The damage to these soils started when the first settlers began cultivating the land and using it for agricultural purposes. The damage is very evident and action must be taken with the utmost immediacy. Erosion, salinity and tree decline are afflicting over half of all agricultural land and poisoning major waterways in this country. The Bill will allow for provision of financial assistance for soil conservation projects undertaken by the Commonwealth, by the States, or by individuals and non-government organisations. It also provides for a Soil Conservation Advisory Committee to provide advice to the Minister concerning allocation of financial assistance and the Commonwealth's role in soil conservation in general.

The Government is approaching the problem of soil conservation in the most serious manner and attributing to it the great emphasis which it urgently needs. Unlike the Opposition, the Government wishes to battle the problems associated with land degradation. The Opposition's record in dealing with this matter is pathetic. It has used soil conservation as a political football, promising the world and delivering nothing. Its approach to the problem of the degradation of the lifeblood of Australian agriculture-soil-has been pitiful. All initiatives in this area have been undertaken by the Australian Labor Party, from the earliest days, and we have seen the seriousness of the problem and attempted to rectify it. The pioneer of soil conservation in this country was that great Australian, a former Premier of New South Wales, the late Sir William McKell. McKell appreciated the significance of the problem of soil degradation. He recalled once how he was reading the then newly published novel by John Steinbeck, The Grapes of Wrath. He said that he remembered how the book started with an old farmer in the United States sitting on his verandah watching his farm blow off in a dust storm. He realised that the same things would happen in Australia but nobody ever said anything about it.

McKell was truly concerned by the problem and his efforts to battle it transcended party lines. Thomas Keneally referred to McKell's efforts in this regard in the 1985 McKell Lectures. He indicated that in 1938 McKell used his influence with Jack Lang to ensure Labor support for the Soil Conservation Bill which was introduced by the Government that year. One interesting highlight of the passage of that Bill was the opposition to it offered by the Country Party. In the debate on the question, the Country Party MLA for Liverpool Plains, a Mr H. C. Carter, offered one of the most absurd statements ever voiced in a parliamentary debate. However, I am sure there are members of the present Opposition who may one day rival him. He said that action against property owners who were guilty of practices which encourage erosion was 'contrary to the best traditions of a Government of British speaking races . . . to empower a committee to order the owner of freehold property not to destroy his timber and do certain other things is altogether wrong. Anyhow, erosion has been going on in Great Britain for thousands of years'. These may have been the ravings of an eccentric member of parliament, but the responses to the problem by the Country Party and the National Party since have been no more productive. Their record speaks for itself. Their approach to soil conservation has been one of political point-scoring and broken promises.

The Commonwealth Government's administrative involvement with soil conservation began shortly after World War II during the period of Labor Government under Ben Chifley, and in 1946 a Standing Committee on Soil Conservation was established. During the following years of coalition rule the problem was starved of attention. In 1975 a national study of land degrading and soil conservation was begun. The study was begun on the main condition that the State and Commonwealth governments 'should collaborate in a study program to establish a basis for a long-term national program of soil conservation in the context of an integrated approach to land management'. In 1976 the Liberal-National Party Government reduced funds available to the States for soil conservation, which program was established in 1974 by the Whitlam Labor Government. This program was intended to be an interim program of financial assistance for the States to step up their soil conservation activities during the period the aforementioned study was prepared. The Labor Government intended the interim grants to be for the beginnings of continued funding for soil conservation programs in the States.
In 1979 the then Minister for National Development, Mr Newman, stated in Parliament:
'My Department will now enter into discussions with the States on a proposal for a national soil conservation program, under which financial assistance would be provided for approved projects.
Mr Newman made this statement when tabling the completed study on soil conservation titled 'A Basis for Soil Conservation Policy in Australia'.

In another grandiose statement, which was, incidentally, made prior to the 1980 election, the coalition promised, as a first step towards a national soil conservation program, an initial $3m in funds for 1981-82. The $3m was to be for the first year of a five-year program, where $12m was to be provided in the fifth year to be matched by State expenditure. However, as has been proven in the past, the electorate could not expect too much from the coalition's promises. In April 1980, the Government's infamous razor gang said that since soil conservation was the responsibility of the States, the Federal Government should leave the field. Subsequently, the Government abandoned the national soil conservation program despite the fact that the States had already had programs prepared for Commonwealth funding. The ridiculous aspect of this move was that the Government included the promised $3m in recurrent grants to the States for the States to use as they wished. The razor gang also called for the abandonment of the Commonwealth extension service and so Commonwealth soil conservation funds in this area were stopped.

In 1983 the coalition staged another one of its pre-election about-faces. The then Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the National Party, Mr Anthony, made another fly-by-night promise regarding soil conservation. While in the Riverina, on his first day of the official campaign, he pledged that if re-elected the Liberal-National Party Government would institute a Commonwealth-funded national soil conservation program. However, Mr Anthony, when making the announcement, would not indicate how much money was to be included in the new plan.

The Opposition's performance in regard to the all-important problem of soil conservation has been one gigantic bungle. It has approached it continually as a political vehicle, regardless of the consequences to the Australian environment. The Hawke Labor Government has produced a Bill which confronts some of the serious problems of land degradation. We will attempt to halt the soil degradation, which is reaching disastrous proportions, and attempt to restore presently degraded land. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Bill is a most important piece of legislation. It underlines a most important principle, which we ignore at our peril: Our land will continue to produce our sustenance, our wealth and our agricultural and pastoral exports only if we are careful in our husbandry. It is a tragedy that, in a country where agriculture has been engaged in for less than 200 years, we have vast areas of salt pans, gullies and scourings where once we had rich, productive crop beds.

SPEECH.PARA: We have cleared and ploughed and sown; we have reaped and profited, often without a thought for tomorrow. Wind, water and sun have depleted and often carried away the rich topsoils in which our crops and pastures grow. This is preventable and in our time of stewardship we have a responsibility or trust to manage and preserve our great asset, the land.

A very pertinent letter was written to the editor of the Australian on Wednesday, 27 March, by the Chairman of the Water Research Foundation of Australia, Mr Jack Beale of Sydney. The letter, headed 'Our erosion as bad as Ethiopia', said:

Scant attention is being given to crucial landscape rejuvenation in the lead-up to the 1985-86 Budget. Cost-effective proposals to revegetate eroded catchments have been ignored while new degradation continues to outpace reparation under low priorities of the Hawke Government.

Either the government does not recognise the economic and social benefits of interconnected water, soil and tree-planting programs or it has deliberately chosen to fund 'quick fix' electorally popular programs rather than take the statesman's harder option of investment in Australia's future.
For example, in two years the Government has cut water works funding (by $70m), investigation (by $3m) and research (by $3m).
Soil conservation expenditure has fallen $4m short. Amenity tree-planting is $1m behind and native species reafforestation down by $10m.

Ill-advised policies are denying both the young and older people stimulating jobs and job training in programs to increase productivity and enhance the environment. Governmental credibility is at risk.

Stark facts are that some Australian eroded areas are as bad as publicised trouble spots in Ethiopia and that continued neglect threatens the living standards of city and country folk alike. I am very proud to say that some decades ago, in the rich red volcanic loam covering the South Burnett district, the farmers faced up to this responsibility, at their own cost, which was considerable, almost crippling, but urgently necessary. I was part of the group who were among the pioneers of contour farming, and as well as contours to prevent scouring of water, wind breaks and grassed banks were established. That was timely and necessary if those rich red soil slopes were to continue to produce their bounty for the farmers, not only then but, also for the generations to follow.

The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) underlined in his speech the great priority of conserving our soil and has produced a Bill which, although entitled a financial assistance Bill, encompasses a concept of Federal Government, State governments, farming and other bodies combining and co-operating in this national task. I am not sure, nor is the Minister, how much money we need to provide. Certainly the provision of huge amounts of money is not always the total answer-it is how that money is applied and to whom it is entrusted that matters. We do not want or need a great bureaucracy eating up funds that may be better applied to ensuring that practical and responsible farmers and advisers have the wherewithal to do the job. We dare not provide too little, or we and posterity will suffer irreparably because of our negligence. I am not sure whether this Bill, which encompasses governments, farmers, the community, departments of primary industry, tertiary institutions, advisers and so on, goes all the way. I do not say that carpingly or critically because it is a beginning. It will need refinement in the light of experience, and will need the dedication and good will of all if it is to progress towards its goals.

The Minister knows, as we all know, that in a program like this vast amounts of money can be swallowed up in administration and in bureaucratic oversight before any of the dollars ever reach the hands of those who will physically perform the work in the field. This is a problem to be faced and overcome or all of the expressed purposes of the Bill, the Minister and the Parliament may be retarded or prevented. I am not critical of the Minister's admission that he cannot quantify the Budget allocation; indeed, I would have been suspicious if he could. What is important is that the amount budgeted is enough to accomplish the task effectively and that it is directed to the proper, practical, productive sources and organisations that can achieve that goal. He will need to be flexible to listen to advice from those who know, till and husband the soil-not the ivory-towered bureaucrats and impractical theorists who have no trouble in spending copious sums of money with little to show for it. I hope, indeed I believe, that this is his intention and in goodwill I suggest that this must be a bipartisan endeavour and resolve. I hope he will, in monitoring this total operation, be willing to listen to and not reject advice and suggestions from all members, particularly from those who have association with the soil and expertise in its husbandry.

The Minister was critical of his predecessors because of what he called their negligence in this area. I do not intend to enter into partisan political argument because it is counter-productive and advances us not one centimetre along the way. For that reason I am trying to be constructive in my consideration and comment on the Bill. However, I want to make some comment on other matters canvassed by the Minister at some length in his speech, which seem to be important in discussion on a Bill designed to achieve effective soil conservation.

The Minister mentioned water conservation and indeed this is an integral part of any total soil conservation program. I hope in the light of his comments in the second reading speech that the Government will now reconsider and reverse its abandonment of the bicentennial water conservation program. I cannot see how we can continue to neglect proper planning and provisioning for the conserving of water if we want to use and husband our soil properly. It is not enough to build dams willy-nilly because a particular position lends itself to the construction of a dam wall. The flow of water in rivers, the amount and type of irrigation permitted, and the construction of dams, weirs and reservoirs as part of a total, well researched program is essential. Every dam must be part of a total planned scheme, not an isolated project, otherwise we will not, in this driest of all continents, make the best and fairest use of our rivers, our rainfall and our run-off.

Soil conservation cannot be isolated from water conservation, the best of soil will not grow crops without water. Nor will the soil continue to produce its bounty unless its conservation is undertaken hand in glove with the conservation and provision of water. So I say to the Minister that all of those aims and hopes which he has expressed, and which we want to see attained, cannot and will not be realised until linked with his plans are plans for the provision and conservation of water. Nor need I point out that one of the greatest agents of erosion is the wind. Its ally is the sun, and dry, powdery, parched soil is quickly lost to these agents. To combat drought, a period of great erosion, to counter the loss of protective grasses and pastures which hold our soil, surely it is evident that management and husbandry of our water is vital. It is a false economy and counter-productive to all of our efforts to conserve our soil to discard, in order to save a few dollars, a water conservation program long overdue, very imaginative, and urgently needed. Let us not argue about who did too little in the past; let us not cavil about the politics of the matter. Our soil and our water are precious resources and we can lose both if we are bad husbandmen. Dollars saved now will be translated into resources lost forever.

So in welcoming and supporting any endeavour or initiative to conserve our soil, I ask that the bicentennial water resources program be very carefully considered within this endeavour. In a bipartisan spirit I say that we must work diligently to protect our resources. A political point scored today might bring us the condemnation of the generations which follow and rely on the productivity of our farm lands. That is why I appeal to the Minister to consider again the water program.

If I failed to present constructively as honestly and clearly as I can the vision I have for conservation of our soils, I would be as guilty of neglect as the Minister would be if he rejected on political grounds alone the proposition I put to him now. I understand time is short, so I will now conclude. I wish the program well for too much time has been wasted and we have little time to arrest the damage and insure for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to support the Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Bill, which deals primarily with farming land, I am mindful of the popular perception in many parts of Australia that a Labor government places a low priority on rural matters. Nothing could be further from the truth. This Government recognises the importance of primary industry and the need to look after the natural resources from which our primary produce is derived. It was many decades before non-Aboriginal Australians understood that the ecology of this country is delicately balanced, that the soil is fragile and arable areas are very limited. Our Government, in its short term in office, has acted to redress the damage done to our productive lands, damage caused largely through ignorance.

SPEECH.PARA: The national soil conservation program, established in 1983, was an important initiative in the restoration and maintenance of healthy and viable agricultural areas. It demonstrates the Government's understanding that agriculture and conservation are inseparable, interdependent mirror-image concepts. The establishment of the program reflects our philosophy of long term planning and of investment in the future for our rural industry. In the 1983-84 Budget the Hawke Government allocated $1m for this program. In 1984-85, $4m was provided. The program makes funds available to State government bodies and non-government groups involved in soil conservation research, training, education or development, or co-ordination of conservation initiatives.

The Bill now before the House is a further step towards the rejuvenation and enhancement of Australia's soils. The Bill sets up a Soil Conservation Advisory Committee which will establish funding priorities for the national soil conservation program. It will give advice and make recommendations on strategies for co-ordinating soil conservation projects nationally. Non-government groups will be encouraged to contribute to discussions about soil conservation issues, and to apply for funding under the program. An organisation in my electorate, Men of the Trees, has developed an idea which is the sort of project which might be considered by the Advisory Committee. Men of the Trees is an international organisation which has as its patron His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales. It is very active in replacing trees in many country areas of Western Australia on a voluntary basis. As I will show today, that organisation has visions that extend beyond that task. It is committed to greening Australia and conserving our soil. Because of this, the Men of the Trees is planning a tree farm project. The benefits of its proposed project are two-fold: To increase and broaden the food production base of Australia but with the important environmental advantages of regeneration and conservation of soils.

It is now widely accepted that trees aid in the prevention of soil erosion. The root system holds the soil in place and a bank of trees will act as a wind break. Trees are considered important in limiting and reversing salt encroachment patterns and in sustaining soil fertility. Water utilisation is enhanced through reduction of erosion. Humus production associated with the tree areas aids water absorption and retention by the soil. The need to understand the value of trees and to develop remedial programs is critical. It is estimated that Western Australia alone is currently losing 25,000 hectares a year through salt encroachment. This represents an annual production loss worth about $26m in the wheatbelt. An estimated $38m has been lost through wind erosion; the cost of water degradation is estimated at $19m; and loss of soil structure is estimated to cost $11m annually. It is also estimated that only 30 per cent of the land in the Western Australian wheatbelt region can be considered stable.

The tree farm proposal recognises the potential dual role of trees as a soil conservation medium and as a food producer. It also acknowledges that there is little comprehensive and practical documentation available on this dual role, and that farms are not geared to take full advantage of this potential. The proposal therefore includes a research component which would aim to build up this database and make it available to farmers. It would also provide valuable information on trees suitable for our climate and soil conditions. The organisation expects that new hybrid varieties, more suited to Australian conditions, may be developed. As a productive enterprise, Men of the Trees envisages the tree farm project will ultimately produce, per year for human consumption, double the protein that can currently be produced by the wheat and sheep farming regions. The tree project would run on existing wheat farms. It would not replace the wheat crops but it would be established as a part of the total farm management system. The tree areas would produce protein through the harvesting of pods or seeds.

By using trees which are capable of fixing nitrogen in the soil and which return other nutrients and humus, the development would be contributing to the reclamation of degraded areas and to the maintenance and conservation of arable areas. In developing an alternative agriculture for degraded wheatbelt areas, the project also aims to stabilise the soil, gradually increase fertility and improve soil health generally.

The Bill under consideration will make provision for financial assistance for projects dealing with soil conservation issues. The tree farm project is an example of a proposal which might be considered for funding under the provisions of the legislation. The Bill gives vital recognition to the depleted and deteriorating condition of our soils-the fundamental element upon which our whole primary industry is based. The Government's commitment to the agricultural sector is reflected in the aim of the Bill-the aim of directing money into soil conservation programs for the protection of this basic resource, and for the future benefit of our primary industry.

In conclusion I wish to congratulate the Government on its initiative in bringing in legislation such as the Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Bill. I would also like to congratulate the Men of the Trees organisation through its tree farm project co-ordinator, Barrie Oldfield, for its proposal to tackle this national problem. I wish it every success for its proposal and will inform the House of what I hope will be its success on soil conservation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be wrong for the House to conclude that the Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Bill will benefit only farmers. Indeed, the impact of this important legislation on soil conservation will assist the community at large in many direct and indirect ways. I point out to the House that many town and city water supplies are very fragile in themselves and rely on a degree of soil conservation to prevent their deterioration. For example, a dam which was connected to the Newcastle water supply scheme some years ago completely silted up through bad soil conservation practices in the area involved. As a consequence, that dam was taken out of the water supply resource of the lower section of the Hunter Valley. I am referring to the Chichester Dam, which I know will be known to my colleagues. It has now been restructured and is in the process of being revamped.

SPEECH.PARA: It follows that progress from improving soil conservation in Australia flows through to communities at large, towns and cities large and small, and also assists State and Federal governments through the plethora of departments which hold land in one form or another. I charge the National Parks and Wildlife Service of New South Wales and other related bodies throughout the different States of Australia with just as much responsibility to exercise proper husbandry of their soils as I do the agricultural community and farmers directly. Of course, farmers, if they have any sense whatsoever would exercise every care and restraint in soil conservation.

As has been mentioned by honourable members, this measure is primarily two-fold in its impact. Firstly, it reaffirms the overall objective of reducing soil degradation in Australia through validating funding from the Federal Government. Secondly, it sets up the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee. I have no quarrel with this funding. I only hope that the funding will lead to effective benefit and progress in reducing soil degradation. In respect of the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee, I believe strongly that State and Federal members of parliament, to name one category of people, should not be automatically barred from membership of that Committee and participation in the Committee should it be the wish of the Government and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) to appoint members of parliament to the Committee.

I made some inquiries of the Minister and his officers as to whether membership of that Committee would constitute an office of profit under the Crown and, therefore, there would be a statutory bar to members of parliament being appointed or taking up membership and holding a seat in this House, in the Senate or in a State parliament. I am advised that, as long as they did not accept any remuneration, it might not constitute an office of profit under the Crown. But this seems to be a grey area and one in which one would need to exercise maximum caution. However, I make the point that there are members of parliament who have a wealth of experience in the area of soil conservation. No matter whether they sit on the government side or the opposition side, I do not for one moment think that just because they are members of parliament they should be banned from serving on such an important advisory committee. In fact, one of the new senators elected on 1 December, Senator David Brownhill, has chaired a valley management soil conservation plan for many years.

He has done a lot of work associated with the catchment in the valley involved. He is recognised as an authority on soil conservation. I realise the political realities, that the likelihood of his appointment at present would be somewhat minimal. Nevertheless, the opportunity should be there for parliamentarians to fulfil roles, extended beyond the more traditional role, by being eligible for appointment to the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee. I hope it is confirmed-if not in this place in another place when the Bill is debated there-that that can be the case.

The question of salinity has been raised repeatedly in this debate, and quite correctly. The honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) has commented on and criticised the Victorian National Party for its contribution on soil conservation and salinity. I reject completely the remarks made by the honourable member for McEwen on this matter. The Deputy Leader of the Victorian National Party, the member for Rodney, served on the Salinity Committee of the Victorian Parliament which produced this most excellent report entitled 'Salt of the Earth'. The member for Rodney, Mr Eddie Hann, the Hon. Bill Baxter, MLC, and many others have led the fight in terms of upgrading the profile of soil conservation and the fight against salinity and are continuing to carry on that work since the most recent Victorian elections.

I further point out that the salinity problem in Victoria exists in every other State, particularly the Darling-Murray basin. It is the Victorian State Government which has failed to act very quickly since the election on the recommendations of the Salinity Committee contained in the report 'Salt of the Earth'. The real lack of activity is with the State Labor Government in Victoria, rather than the Victorian National Party, which has had a very strong track record on this particular issue. However, I do not want to dwell on that because it is a measure which enjoys bipartisan support and the debate, by and large, has evoked bipartisan comments.

There has been a general recognition in recent years of the massive impact of salinity on the Darling-Murray basin embracing the States of Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. It has reached the stage where New South Wales, Victoria and part of Queensland are contributing 1.1 million tonnes of salt in suspension each year to the Murray River at the point where it flows into South Australia. South Australia adds another half-million tonnes of salt. The maximum salt load carried in suspension in the Murray River is 1.6 million tonnes. A lot of that is salt naturally occurring, but a lot relates to soil degradation and incorrect farming practices. It is a complex area which I will not go into in detail other than to point out that a lot of the laser work being carried at at present is very constructive. It has done much to reduce the waterlogging which adds to salinity and has improved soil composition. Laser land planing is very costly work, especially when carried out in a sophisticated form. The biggest cost component associated with that work is the cost of fuel.

I reject what the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) has said, that the Government has taken care of rural areas. Since 1 December there has been a massive increase in the cost of fuel and that is boomeranging right across the whole agricultural situation adding to the cost-price squeeze on farmers. Above all, it is adding to the cost of carrying out laser land planing which, in turn, does help reduce soil degradation, a matter relative to the measure before the House. The thrust of the Bill in terms of validating funding of soil conservation on the one hand and of setting up the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee on the other is most welcome.

In conclusion, I repeat my appeal that members of parliament, whether they be from the Government side or the Opposition side, might be considered for appointment to the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee should they have the experience. I can say only that Australia would have been a more mature place politically if, in fact, Malcolm Fraser had acted shortly after 1976 by extending an appropriate ambassadorial appointment to the then former Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam. It would have been appropriate if the current Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, had seen fit to appoint Malcolm Fraser to an appropriate ambassadorship. I kindly suggest that that might have been a place such as Zimbabwe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australian primary producers rank with the most efficient in the world, yet despite many technological and commercial achievements, Australian land users have generally failed to develop or adhere to land management systems that are consistent with long term sustainable utilisation of soil resources. Australian soils are developed on an ancient landscape and the soils are often leached and infertile. Because of Australia's unique and fragile ecological environment, many Australian soils are unable to support a robust vegetation. There is a great range of climate, soil and land forms in this country but, despite its wide open spaces, Australia has relatively small areas of fertile soils in areas of medium to high rainfall.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past 100 years little allowance has been made for the frequency of droughts, floods or for limited slope soil structure or ground water hydrology in land management. Farmers and graziers have been able to do very much as they pleased in the name of progress and productivity. The strength and diversity of Australian primary production owes an enormous debt to the pioneers who settled and tamed the wilderness. Historically many farmers and graziers have been burdened by a long established legacy of environmental neglect and misuse which has threatened their profitability and in some instances, their very existence.

The magnitude of the problem is difficult to grasp. In 1978 a joint Commonwealth-State study found that some 270 million hectares, or just over half the area in agricultural and pastoral use, required treatment for land degradation if its productivity was to be maintained. The alternative to taking action is a continued loss of productivity of agricultural land. Many of our pastoral lands are seriously or even critically degraded. Infertility in many tropical soils now supporting crops such as sugar-cane and bananas appears to be a significant problem.

Soil erosion is a problem of major concern in the semi-arid tropical region of Australia. The Queensland Government has not developed measures to arrest accelerating soil degradation in northern Australia. An example of a region with an incipient erosion problem is the Burdekin catchment area of north Queensland. The major form of land use in this area located in the semi-arid tropics is extensive grazing by beef cattle. It has been the major form of land use since the land was first settled by Europeans around 1870. The area is generally unsuitable for cropping not only because of the unreliability of the rainfall and the short growing season but also because of infertile soils. Those pockets of cropping which do exist are small in area and are likely to herald an expansion of production. However, crop production in southern Queensland has expanded over the last 15 years and consequently the northern areas of Queensland are becoming more important as beef producing areas.

The beef industry in northern Australia was originally developed at low stocking rates using British breed cattle-for example, Shorthorns, Herefords and Devons. This form of land use lasted for nearly 100 years but apparently without a great deal of damage to the soil. Some Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation scientists of the Davies Laboratory at Townsville believe this was because British breeds of cattle were poorly adapted to the semi-arid tropical environment where high temperatures and the poor quality of the native pastures kept their numbers in check. During the droughts, large numbers of these animals died and the reproduction rate of cows was very low, frequently averaging 55 per cent. Economically, this situation could not persist and a method of improving production had to be found. During the last 20 years there has been a radical change in the breed of cattle. This has been brought about by the infusion of Zebu bloodlines into the herds by the use of suitable bulls. These cattle, which originated in India, are much more tolerant of high temperatures and also appear to have a better survival rate on poor quality feeds than British breed cattle.

At the same time another important development has occurred. Chemical supplements to the poor quality pasture have become readily available. In north Queensland, the grazing industry is seizing on both of these developments in order to obtain economic viability. The success of these developments is evident in the greater survival of the cattle. The north Queensland region now supports almost twice as many cattle as it did in 1960. But there has been an environmental cost. The native grasses in this area were able to persist under the light stocking of 20 years ago and they provided a sufficient cover to protect the soils. However, because the environment is a stressful one for plant growth, that is, with low soil fertility and semi-arid climate, the grasses are not able to cope with the heavier grazing which now exists. Native grasses are losing vigour and dying. The result is that soil in many areas is becoming exposed.

Rainfall in the semi-arid tropics is general low and variable. However, the region also has very high intensity rainfall. Torrens Creek, for example, has an average annual rainfall of 550 millimetres, the great bulk of which falls between December and March, often in heavy falls of short duration. In one case a rainfall of 42 millimetres in just 24 minutes was recorded. Ideal conditions for sheet erosion then occur. In 1976 the Burdekin project committee estimated that 12.4 per cent of the Upper Burdekin catchment, which contains an area of 5.9 million hectares, had suffered sheet and gully erosion of up to approximately 28 tonnes per hectare per year.

There are many examples which establish that it is possible to carry heavy stocking rates without severe loss of cover by using improved pastures. Improved pastures are well known in southern Australia but in northern Australia they are a comparatively recent development. Improved pastures rely on the use of fertilisers, especially phosphorous, and the discovery of legumes adapted to the environment. One important discovery is the new process for making phosphorous fertiliser from the deposits at Duchess in north Queensland. Equally important is the discovery by the CSIRO of legumes from South America which are adapted to the semi-arid tropics and which increase cattle growth more effectively than chemical supplements. The stocking rates which can be achieved on improved pastures are in the vicinity of ten times greater than on native pastures. This represents a quantum leap in capacity and would provide a method of reducing grazing pressure on native pastures. At present few graziers have introduced this technology, partly because it is new and partly because they are uncertain of the financial benefits. Clearly the pace of scientific study of the semi-arid region of northern Australia must be accelerated. The CSIRO laboratory at Townsville is well equipped to carry out this research. Scientists at that laboratory are involved in the study of pastures, soils and tropical cattle. This urgent research is being hampered by a lack of financial support.

Another example of soils at risk of erosion are those of the wet coast in northern Queensland. In this region intensive cropping is practical on soils which 120 years ago carried rain forest. Measurement of soil loss in this region has been estimated at 150 tonnes per hectare per year, and one measurement showed a loss of 382 tonnes per hectare in January 1981 after rainfall of 2,742 millimetres. The cause of erosion on the tropical soils is associated with the loss of organic matter which occurs after clearing and intensive cropping. This problem, incidentally, is unique to Australia but the cause has been identified only recently. Here again we need to use technology if we are to maintain the resource and also our standard of living. It would appear that the solution to this problem will involve adding organic matter to the soils as well as other additives which will prevent the losses of plant foods. Without these, root development is impaired and soils are not as effectively held during the period of high rainfall. In addition, it is probable that there will have to be new methods of cultivation using less machinery. These are known as no-till methods and have been shown to be effective in reducing surface erosion. In north Queensland soil erosion probably has another undesirable effect, that is, that soil pollution of the sea probably has an effect on the growth of the Great Barrier Reef. Scientists at the Australian Institute of Marine Science have shown that the past climate of the continent is reflected by cores taken from the reef. This proves that the reef is not a separate ecosystem which is divorced from the land. Protection of the reef is clearly of paramount importance to our national heritage.

The Federal Government can influence the course of events of soil conservation by providing special purpose financial assistance subject to whatever conditions it thinks fit. This long overdue Bill will provide a statutory basis for Federal Government involvement in this area. The Bill will provide the necessary machinery to give leadership for interstate co-ordination and co-operation.

This Bill has three major functions: First, the regulation of financial assistance for soil conservation measures; second, the creation of a Commonwealth soil conservation program fund; and third, the formation of a Soil Conservation Advisory Committee to advise on priorities and the operation of this Bill. Financial assistance will now become available for soil conservation projects undertaken by the Commonwealth, by the States or by individuals and non-government organisations. Clause 6 of the Bill is of particular interest in that it allows wide scope for the Minister for Primary Industry to develop soil conservation measures with associations, statutory authorities, or other organisations and private individuals. Agreements to provide assistance made between the Minister and such organisations or other persons must be in writing. Clause 7 of the Bill deals with conditions that are to be applied to such agreements and the supervision of such expenditure. Clauses 8 and 9 of the Bill establish the National Soil Conservation Program Fund. The fund will be a trust account for the purposes of section 62A of the Audit Act 1901. Income will be received from, inter alia, amounts appropriated by Parliament, interest, gifts and bequests.

The Hawke Government, an authentic Australian Government, established the national soil conservation program in 1983 and made $1m available to the program in 1983-84. Recognising the success of this program, the Hawke Government made $4m available for the program in 1984-85. This Bill will now enable further assistance to be made available. Clauses 10 to 17 create the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee. Clause 11 details the membership of the Committee. Up to four persons with special knowledge of soil conservation can be appointed to the Committee. I call on the Minister to appoint a suitably qualified north Queenslander to this Committee.

The land, no matter who the owner, is the one true asset when everything else is stripped away. The land belongs to the entire community no matter who, for the time being, may own pieces of it. It goes to make up the topography and the substance of what we call Australia. In that sense this Bill will help safeguard this resource through responsible control. The link between agriculture and conservation is fundamental to a healthy rural sector. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has been indefatigable in his crusade to have the Commonwealth take an important role in actively encouraging and co-ordinating conservation of our land resources. The successful implementation of this Bill will earn for him the enduring gratitude of all Australians conscious of their responsibility to preserve, protect and defend their national heritage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very pleased to hear the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) emphasise the importance of our soil to the nation. I know he is most genuine in his approach. I was also pleased to listen to the address of the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). I recall the honourable member for Farrer, when he was in the New South Wales Parliament, taking me on a tour of his electorate when I was the Minister responsible for agriculture and water resources. We went to the Wakool area, which is an irrigation district along the Murray. We saw people reclaiming land that was affected by salinity, pumping water one and a half times saltier than the sea into the drains as an experiment, and actually reclaiming the land. That makes one appreciate just how important it is that we care for the soil we have. I know that the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) has often spoken in this chamber of his concern for this area because it is a part of Australia that is very seriously affected by salinity.

SPEECH.PARA: Soil is very precious to a nation. I believe that, as the years have passed, individuals have appreciated the responsibility they have in the building up and retention of the quality of our soil. I am pleased to see the Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Bill before the Parliament. I believe that as a Commonwealth we should be involved with soil conservation. I must say that soil conservation departments in the States-I speak principally of New South Wales-are very responsible in the work they are doing. Over the years they have reclaimed quite an amount of land that certainly by today would have been washed away to sea or blown away, with their contour drains, or damaged by some of the other things that are taking place on the land. The departments have given encouragement to land owners generally to undertake soil conservation works on their properties. I would be very pleased to know that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has in mind-he mentioned this in the second reading speech on the Bill-spending some of the money on the promotion of better means of soil conservation on the farm. Every person who owns land in Australia has a great responsibility to ensure that the crops he is planting and the way he is working his property combine with an overall plan to retain the soil and the soil quality we have.

I mention the New South Wales Soil Conservation Service principally because I know of the work it has done, even in the Captains Flat area near Queanbeyan on the Molonglo River. Certain works were carried out there in 1975-76 that have had a lasting result in that part of the State. But emphasis must be placed on the fact that, as well as soil conservation departments, in conjunction with the Commonwealth, carrying out their work, encouragement should be given to individual land owners in order that they can adopt the necessary means to improve their soil. I refer to taxation measures and the general subsidies that at one time-I am not sure whether they are provided today by the States-were provided in New South Wales for land owners to undertake their own work under the supervision of the conservation department. More will be achieved by that individual approach to conservation throughout Australia than by all the work that either State or Commonwealth governments can do. That is why I emphasise the fact that no matter what we do as governments, State or Commonwealth, the important things are to encourage the farmer to know more about the prospects of improving and saving the soil and to present to him incentives to enable him to do the things that are necessary for his own good and for the good of the nation.

It concerns me greatly when looking at the Budgets of the Commonwealth and States to see that greater emphasis is not placed upon water and soil conservation. The emphasis appears to have drifted away from these important things which are the life-blood of a nation. Today, most of our financial resources appear to go to other fields, such as social security and Medicare. I do not condemn those very necessary things, but what this country will prosper from in the years to come will be the retention of the soil, which will enable the farmer to produce more upon his land. Even though we now have problems with the dairy industry, the sugar industry and so on, in five years time things may be different. The situation can change overnight. This country will have a great responsibility to export food, whether it is butter, grain, sugar or some other income earner, to feed a world that wants food. That is the important thing. If our soil is good we will be able to do that. We should encourage the farmer to stay on his farm, by offering taxation deductions, a small subsidy of some kind, by letting him see that everybody wants to help him. He will learn from his neighbour or from the fellow further down the stream what measures he should adopt. These are the practical things we should do as a nation. That is why I emphasise once again the importance of the farmer.

As for the person in the street, why can he not plant more trees? The sesquicentenary is approaching and the bicentenary is coming up. Why cannot planting trees be undertaken as a project? I know that many people are thinking of this. Is it not important to encourage everyone to plant more trees, whether one has a block of land in a metropolitan area, out west or on the coast, and no matter what one is producing? I can remember seeing on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation television channel about a year ago satellite pictures showing how, over the years, we have denuded Australia of trees, how our desert area has encroached on the agricultural lands of Australia. I do not know where those early pictures came from, but they record what has happened. I do not question them. All I want to say is that this is something that is happening within Australia. The best way we can avert a situation such as I have described and change the system is by encouraging people who own land to plant trees and undertake the conservation works that are so important. One can help to conserve the soil by planting certain types of grasses. Up and down the coast I have seen what the soil conservationer has been able to achieve with the sand dunes, yet I see our coastal streams silting up because dirt is washing down from the mountains. One should appreciate the work the forestry commissions are doing. They are the greatest conservationists one could find anywhere.

I certainly support the Bill, which I believe is a move forward. I was sorry to see the Commonwealth at one time ceasing the provision of assistance to the States for soil conservation. I trust that the Minister will appoint to the advisory body people with a knowledge of agriculture. That is very important. People with the knowledge of agriculture also have a knowledge of soil conservation. I hope that the emphasis in this area does not go to the way-out conservationists but ends up in the practical field where it ought to be. If it does not, the assistance the Commonwealth gives might as well go down the drain. I hope that the advisory body will not be a bureaucratic--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Time does not allow me to respond in full to all the points made in this very full and long debate on the Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Bill. Basically, the debate was marked by a lack of politics. Of course, what the Commonwealth is doing is involving the State governments, the farmers themselves and experts in the field of soil conservation. A lot of the politics has been taken out of the debate. However, I point out to the House that there was a lot of politics involved in this matter when I debated it previously as Opposition spokesman for primary industry with the now Leader the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair). Of course, he opposed vehemently any involvement by the Commonwealth in soil conservation. Mr Punch, the Leader of the National Party in the New South Wales Parliament, also said that the Commonwealth had no business in soil conservation.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we all owe a great debt to Prime Minister Whitlam and Minister Cass for the role they played in soil conservation and its study in this country. I mention, for example, the 1978 study which was the most comprehensive work ever done in Australia on soil conservation. Of course, all that work was sabotaged by the previous Government and the unhappy person who had to do that sabotaging was Mr Newman. That was all a result of the razor gang. The honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) has just made a point on practicality. I say in reply that we are working with farmers and conservation groups. I point out that tax deductibility is not always practical in regard to soil conservation matters because one man's soil conservation problem could be caused by someone way up the catchment area some 20 miles away.

This Parliament will have to accept that if we are to do constructive work on soil conservation and prevention of land degradation, which is a more important concept, we will have to do something in a comprehensive way about the Murray-Darling system and not always resile from the vapid arguments of States rights. However, we do not have to go along with the Fraser gimmickry in backing the Bradfield plan which would have turned north-west Queensland into a saltpan. Also we are going to have to stop this nonsense which is occurring at present in the Daintree. Of course, the soil conservation measures which are taking place are all policies of absolute destruction and all in the interests of real estate development. Therefore, let us not pretend that there is not still some politics involved in this.

What the Commonwealth is doing is working with the States and the farmers and trying to give a lead. It is not just a question of spending money; it is a question of getting the policies right. I will respond in writing to the points made by honourable members where further clarification is required. The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), as Opposition spokesman, posed specific questions which I will reply to.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
