SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian community, in its nearly 200-year history, has achieved much as a peaceful, just and compassionate democratic capitalist society, proud of its achievements in defending freedom in overseas wars, in developing its economy to the point where the country has one of the highest standards of living in the world and in ensuring its social programs are used largely to assist those in greatest need. The bases for our achievements have included our British heritage, alliances with overseas democracies, our constitutional monarchy, freedoms of speech and association, Christian values, rule of law, the major role played by private enterprise and our entrepreneurs, the strength of the family unit and the successful assimilation of all peoples into a relatively socially harmonious society.

SPEECH.PARA: In these circumstances, Mr Speaker, it comes as something of a considerable surprise to read 'Bicentenary '88: Special issue', released by the Australian Bicentennial Authority, which outlines the program for the celebration of our 200 years of history. The theme 'Living Together' is bad enough-it is insipid, uninspiring and reminiscent of the political tortures of the past two years-but to have discarded in its favour the theme 'The Australian Achievement' is unthinkable. Then we have the emphasis on the 'diversity of cultural groups that have settled here in successive waves of immigration', without any emphasis on our extraordinary achievement in coalescing those groups to produce a free and unified society. The program focuses on concepts of race, religion and age, without any mention of the critical role played by our Christian values, constitutional monarchy, parliamentary democracy, federalism and other institutions. In particular, Mr Speaker, you will be disappointed, perhaps appalled, to learn that at no stage does the program give any attention to the roles of free elections, this Parliament, the way we make our laws or the peaceful nature of their implementation. Needless to say there is, however, one institution that is favourably featured for its role in building the nation, and that is the trade union movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on. That is a nonsense.

—I will go on. It is doubtful whether our forebears would any longer be proud of the trade unions, which were originally established to protect the weaker worker and which now, in their role as creator of the insufferable job protection cartel, positively discriminate against him. But nowhere in the program do we have a comparable reference to market freedoms, private enterprise and the role of the entrepreneur in creating the wealth that has made it possible for us to institute advanced social programs.

SPEECH.PARA: The booklet on the proposed program for the Bicentennial seems to gloss over our historical performance and hard work in harsh natural conditions for a positive adulation of recreation and leisure, neglecting the tough truth that our ability to have leisure activities results only from the proper application of the virtues of productive work. Women's activities receive much emphasis but there is virtually no mention made of the most important role women play in our society, namely, the establishment of, and the succour and support they give to the family unit.

Finally, our Australian flag, which is highly regarded by the vast majority of Australians, appears nowhere in the booklet; rather the Bicentennial Authority has adopted its own mishmash version. Our flag, showing our historic links to Great Britain, our unity of States and Commonwealth, and our geographic position under the Southern Cross, is a symbol of the Australian achievement and all that this society stands for and will move toward in the future. Furthermore, nowhere is there any mention of the many thousands of our citizens who fought under the flag to protect our freedom. The Authority's emphasis on the cultural disorganisation of our society and the divisive rather than cohesive themes to be emphasised in the celebrations is in urgent need of review. The sense of having inherited a worthy past is essential to a feeling of having a worthwhile future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take a few minutes tonight to speak about some research that has been conducted in recent years into the possible problems associated with coming into close association with the herbicide 2,4,5-T. There appears to be some sort of linkage-although nothing is yet proven-between exposure to 2,4,5-T and central nervous system defects. There is possibly a closer link to the incidence of talipes. This was shown in some research which was conducted in New Zealand. There was also some research in Sweden, and again in New Zealand, which showed a possible connection with exposure to 2,4,5-T and the incidence of soft tissue sarcoma. There have been some interesting results with exposure of chickens. There is possibly a connection with exposure to 2,4,5-T and a drop in the level of mental effectiveness.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer members who may be interested in this to a number of articles in the New Scientist in 1981. Oral toxicity also varies quite markedly in animals, but there are no known toxicity levels for man. Toxicity can occur at a chronic exposure rate lower than a single dose. Interestingly, rats will show an acute toxicity reaction at 500 milligrams per kilo of body weight, but chronic exposure also exists with rats between 50 and 500 milligrams per kilogram body weight. I make these comments in response to some comments made by a member of this House in the adjournment debate on 26 March. I quote from an article that appeared in the Forbes Advocate on 4 April 1985. It is entitled 'Peace Studies Again', and reads:

Speaking in Parliament last week the Member for Parkes, Mr Michael Cobb, attacked the 'Sam Lewis Peace Awards', presented by the New South Wales Teachers Federation to school children working for peace.
The article went on to say that Sam Lewis was a communist and was an inappropriate idol to hold up for children. It stated further:
But as the Member for Calare, Mr David Simmons, pointed out during debate in the house, he didn't consume strange substances.
They then listed some of the incidents from the Hansard debate. It reads:
COBB: Sam Lewis was the President of the NSW Teachers Federation.
SIMMONS: He did not drink 2,4,5-T.

COBB: This will be a little hard for the honourable member (Mr Simmons) to swallow. The interjection from Mr Simmons was a reference to the fact that Mr Cobb drank a glass of 2,4,5-T at a National Party Conference some years ago to prove it harmless.
In view of Mr Cobb's comments about setting up a good example for children, the question is, as the article went on to say:
The question is: is drinking 2,4,5-T a good example to set children?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) last night spoke in the adjournment debate and suggested that I was being far too emotional about the assets test. If I was emotional, it was with very good reason. That very good reason is that I care about the vast procession of people coming before me and most other members of this House. We on this side of the House care about those people. That is why I make no apology for becoming emotional about something that I believe is absolutely vital. As far as I can see the assets test is being choked up with a vast number of pensioners who are losing their pensions or having their pension reduced by the valuations of the Australian Taxation Office. Many of the valuations are just totally unrealistic. In many cases, if not most cases, the house and curtilage valuations are reduced by at least 50 per cent and the value of the remaining land is inflated. It appears this is done so that the pensioners will be persecuted and lose part or all of their pension.

SPEECH.PARA: I give one example at Boambee near Coffs Harbour, where a house and curtilage was given a taxation value of $55,000, whereas the real value was $138,000. On the three-acre orchard attached to that, with a shed and tools, the tax value was inflated to $107,000 whereas the real value was only $24,000. That is absolutely typical of so many cases that I am finding every day of every week since this has come about. What is worse, we have the situation of rubber stamp valuations. There are files which bear the stamp 'assessment made from local knowledge-no inspection made'. We have a situation where valuers are sitting at a desk and thinking of a number.

The Minister for Social Security continually speaks of the hardship provisions, and so he should because there is a great deal of hardship. He has already told us that the Government has no provisions for emergency funding for destitute pensioners. He refuses to tell us how long the hardship hearings will take and how long the taxation valuation appeals will take. This may be unimportant to him, but to pensioners who are anxiously waiting to see whether their pension will be restored, it is all important. We need to know how long the hearings will take and how long pensioners will have to survive without income. Will the pension payment be backdated if it is reinstated under the hardship provisions; how many cases have been heard so far; why is it all being kept secret; and how many dejected and destitute Australians are waiting despondently in the queue of despair? Why will the Minister not tell us.

What is the assets test really about? As far as I can see, there are four significant factors. First, it penalises people for wanting to live on land which they have worked all their lives and on which they have raised their children. Secondly, it is a policy of forced relocation, faintly-I agree only faintly-reminiscent of South Africa and Russia, whereby pensioners are being forced to sell up and buy a house in town, or to live off the proceeds. The third point is that it imposes a gift tax on pensioners. Why are they being discriminated against? The rest of us in this society do not pay gift taxes or gift duties, but if a pensioner couple give away more than $4,000 a year to their children or to charity, they are being taxed on it. The fourth point, which I believe is the most important, is that it provides the framework and the basic data for the reintroduction of death duties. Is this the real reason for the assets test-the easy introduction of death duties?

The Government has established the Doomsday Book of Australian pensioners. Like a flock of circling vultures, it is sizing up all of our parents and grandparents, recording their assets, so that when the time comes the Government can rush in and get its greedy claws on the fruits of a lifetime of work by so many decent Australians. The assets test must go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few words in relation to the assets test and to take up the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) on some of the points he raised. We are consistently hearing the rhetoric of members on the other side in relation to the assets test, yet we do not seem to have anything constructive coming from them. Let me put before the Parliament a few facts and figures which should be made clear.

SPEECH.PARA: The number of pensioners affected by the assets test is 2.6 per cent of all pensioners in Australia. That is only slightly above the original estimate of 2 per cent. Some 97.4 per cent, or more than two million, of the pensioners have not had their pensions reduced by even one cent. We are talking about 2.6 per cent of the pensioners in Australia. We have in that 2.6 per cent a minute group who are having some difficulties which need to be ironed out, because of valuations and other small adjustments, and we are prepared to admit that. But there were many pensioners and many people in the community who were avoiding the income test. Those people actually forced the position whereby the assets test had to be brought into operation in order to ensure that those people who avoided the income test did not receive a pension if they are not entitled to it. They are the great majority of the 2.6 per cent. Some 30,291 pensions out of more than two million have been cancelled-a very small number indeed. Another 23,000 to 24,000 people have had their pensions reduced. For those 23,000 or 24,000 people there are some problems in relation to valuations, but we must always remember--

TALK.START.PARA: —What do they live on in the meantime?
—In the meantime provisions have been made and fine tuning of the administration is taking place. Regional directors around Australia--
—Big deal!
—Order! An amount of interjection is expected in an adjournment debate, but excessive interjection affects my visual acuity.

—The regional directors around Australia are now in a position to access many of the cases, the details of which are sitting on their desks and which they know from local knowledge there are problems with. I recommend to members of the Opposition that they do the same things as members of the Government do on behalf of their constituents. When they have problems with pensioners, the first priority should be the care and concern of the pensioners who have been mistreated or whom the wrong decision has been made. It appears to me that a great deal of attention is being paid to playing politics rather than to doing the correct thing by the pensioners. Members opposite should take cases to the regional offices of the Department of Social Security so that where there are anomalies-we admit that there are clear anomalies in some areas-they can be fixed with local knowledge. We expect that that will be done quickly. It is of no help to the pensioners of Australia to have a constant barrage of politicians using them for vote winning purposes at their expense. The pensioners should not be used in that manner.

SPEECH.PARA: Over two million pensioners, or 97.4 per cent, have not been affected by one cent. Another group should never have been getting pensions in the first place. Surely those opposite do not support the dishonest pensioners who were avoiding the income test. Surely none of them supports the person who had assets totalling $909,000 in addition to another property valued at $905,000 declaring no income and thus being entitled to a pension. I cite another case of a person who had assets worth $560,000, including a property worth $267,000, with cash in various bank accounts of $279,000. He was getting a full pension because he declared no income. Those opposite cannot defend people who were cheating the system. Let us be honest about the people we are concerned about. We on this side of the House are just as concerned, in fact more concerned, because we are taking the problems we receive directly to the Department where something can be done about them. I suggest to members of the Opposition that, if they want to support the pensioners in their areas, they should take the problems to their regional directors. They have the opportunity to do something about those problems, but they cannot do anything about them unless they are told.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 March, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) made some allegations about my conduct whilst I was Acting Attorney-General in 1982. I have now examined the papers in the Attorney-General's Department on the matter and wish to correct the record. The Attorney-General on 22 March referred for some reason to the case of a man who is still awaiting retrial. I will refer to this man as 'X', although the Attorney-General had no qualms about giving his name in public. The man had been committed for trial on two charges, conspiracy and forgery.

SPEECH.PARA: The substance of the Attorney-General's allegation was that I had decided in 1982 not to prosecute 'X' on the forgery charge. In fact, he repeated the allegation several times. That allegation is false. The Attorney-General also said:
There was a decision on 1 November 1982. The honourable member made the decision, unilaterally. Let us make that very clear.
That allegation is also false. The Attorney-General also said:
It is a matter of record. There were two charges and you dropped one, by your own indications.
That allegation is also false. The Attorney-General then referred to a document which he described as 'the record' and it was subsequently tabled. He said that this record showed:
On 24 September 1982 a submission was made to Acting Attorney-General Brown indicating that the latest representations did not change the earlier recommendation; that is, the two charges stand.

The Attorney-General has misled this House because the record, which is a chronology prepared by Mr B. H. Leader of the Attorney-General's Department, does not say ' . . . that the two charges stand' or anything like it. The Attorney-General then went on to quote from this so-called record again:

The Acting Attorney-General obtained the Solicitor-General's opinion that the trial should proceed. On 1 November the Acting Attorney-General decided that the trial should proceed on the conspiracy charge-one charge, not two.

Again, the record does not say that I decided that the trial should proceed on one charge, not two. There is no doubt that what the Attorney-General was putting to this House was that a submission was made to me that this man should stand trial on the two charges of conspiracy and forgery; that that recommendation was supported by the opinion of the Solicitor-General; that I rejected the submission and the opinion, and that I ordered that one charge be dropped, the forgery charge, and that the man should stand trial only on one charge, the conspiracy charge. Each of those allegations is false; each of them is a misrepresentation. None of them is supported by the record the Attorney-General pretended to quote from or the file in the Attorney-General's Department. The Attorney-General then repeated all of this by saying:
The point is that the committal was on two charges and the trial was on one. The discretion not to proceed on the other was the decision made on 1 November.

That allegation is false. But the matter is far worse than these simple falsehoods. The Attorney-General omitted from his attack on me any reference to the fact that the question of whether the trial should proceed on the forgery charge was not before me. It was not a decision for me to make, as it had already been made by the Crown Law officers in Sydney. Let me establish this by referring to the Departmental papers on the case. First, the same Mr Leader made a submission to the then Attorney-General on 10 August. This said that the accused was charged with conspiracy and with forgery. It then said:

The Deputy Crown Solicitor has advised, however, that as the forgery charge is subsumed within the conspiracy charge, if the trial is to proceed it is proposed to present an indictment on the conspiracy charge only.
Secondly, one of the documents supporting that submission came from the Deputy Crown Solicitor and that said:
. . . it is proposed that as the forgery charge is subsumed within the conspiracy, an indictment would be presented on the conspiracy charge alone.

It is clear from all the documents in the file that the question of whether to proceed on the forgery charge was not before me or before Senator Durack. The Deputy Crown Solicitor in Sydney had decided that this man would not stand trial for forgery and that was that. The Attorney-General should table all of the papers, so that all honourable members can see the facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I come from an area in the western central highlands of Victoria which is, perhaps, one of the most historic areas in Australia. In fact, in many respects it has given the democracy which we hope we enjoy the basis for its development. This is a most significant tourist area as well. The city of Ballarat is the most beautiful Victorian city and probably has no equal in the Commonwealth. Because of its current tourist industry and its potential, I mentioned some time ago to Mr Kevin Irving, who is the manager of the Goldfields Tourism Authority in Ballarat, that we should establish a seminar on tourism to attempt to get some kind of co-ordination into the tourist industry in that community. It was not as though some organisation was not already in existence, but the organisation did not go right across the whole spectrum of those people who were concerned-those involved in the hospitality industry through to the food outlets; in fact, everybody who had something to sell which would encourage tourism. I suppose my primary motive in doing this was to provide opportunities for the development of more jobs in that area. I am pleased to say that Mr Irving has taken up this idea, along with Mr David Newton, Chairman of the Ballarat Promotion Committee, and a number of others, and that on 30 May a seminar will be held. It will be attended by people from all sorts of organisations, including local government. I think it is extremely important that ideas of this kind be encouraged. I am particularly pleased that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) will be opening that seminar.
—Don't let him use a hire car.
—The honourable member for Denison knows all about the use of a company car; ask him.

—Yes, I think the honourable member should direct his comments elsewhere. I suggest that people in other areas might well take up initiatives of this kind. Ballarat, which has Sovereign Hill and a great range of existing tourist facilities, is a city with an old industrial base. That industrial base, while currently thriving under the economic policies of the present Government, nevertheless will not provide the job opportunities it provided in the past. Fifteen per cent of our population are unemployed and many of these are the unskilled and the young. Tourism is a most significant industry for us. Possibly $60m comes into the Ballarat community from tourism, with 430,000 people per annum passing through the Sovereign Hill Historical Park alone.

SPEECH.PARA: I have raised this matter tonight because there must be other people in other places who recognise that this industry will provide for many of those with few skills who have left school early the opportunity to gain a job in a new career industry. I hope that we will have something to offer to other members of the House as a result of the success of this seminar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This summer Australia suffered yet another disastrous bushfire season. Many homes, a great deal of property and a number of lives were lost as a result of the bushfires in this country. In the Goulburn area, in the electorate of Gilmore, some 28,000 hectares of property was destroyed as a result of these bushfires. These bushfires are costing the nation a great deal of money. When one looks back to the summer of 1982-83 one can see the cost that this nation is suffering as a result of bushfires. In the 1982-83 summer some two million hectares of forest were destroyed; approximately 5 per cent of the total forest area in Australia. In that summer 2,528 homes were destroyed, 77 lives were lost and the damage bill for bushfires in the State of South Australia alone came to some $209m. What are we doing in this country to try to overcome these losses incurred as a result of bushfires? What is this Government doing to instigate legislation to create some sort of activity in this country to minimise the losses that we suffer, seemingly every summer, as a result of bushfires?

SPEECH.PARA: We heard last night the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) speak about the Surf Life Saving Association of Australia introducing the innovative idea of using helicopters and aircraft to save lives. That is a good idea, and I think the Government ought to be doing something as innovative as that. The previous Government introduced a project called Project Aquarius, which was set up to carry out research into bushfire fighting and in particular to research the use of large aircraft in that field. Unfortunately, in its so-called wisdom this Government decided to cease the operations of Project Aquarius and, as a result, there will be no further activity. The research that has been carried out will not be completed and work that could have done something useful for this country will not be instigated. As I said, Project Aquarius was looking into the possible use of large aircraft to fight bushfires. In the United States of America, Canada and France large aircraft such as the Grumman Tracker have for some time been used to fight bushfires. They have been used effectively, efficiently and safely, and have been proven to have a cost benefit advantage to those countries. The Grumman aircraft have a proven track record, and honourable members might wonder why we do not utilise them. Australia does have 17 Grumman Tracker aircraft. They are currently stationed at HMAS Albatross at Nowra and since August of last year this Government has been trying to sell them to the highest bidder. I point out that the highest bidder is probably going to bid only somewhere between $70,000 and $100,000 for each of those aircraft. Yet since August last year Australia has been going up in smoke. We have had one of the worst bushfire seasons ever.

Since January of this year I have been in constant contact with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and other Ministers of this Government, pleading with them to stop the sale of these Tracker aircraft, to keep them in Australia and to convert them into bushfire fighting units, so that we can save property, homes and lives to the benefit of all Australians. I plead now with this Government to stop the sale of these aircraft. I suggest, Mr Speaker, that while this Government fiddles Australia will burn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keogh Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had the opportunity in Question Time this afternoon to put a question to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in regard to the present state of the Queensland economy. The Prime Minister, in his very concise answer to my question-it was not possible for him to go into any great detail about the economic situation in Queensland due to the time available-dealt very briefly with a few of the facts that I am sure illustrated very clearly to honourable members the disgraceful situation into which the Queensland economy has deteriorated due very much to the deliberate actions of the Queensland Premier, who of course just happens to be also the Treasurer of Queensland. With all those facts that were given to the House today by the Prime Minister, that man, Bjelke-Petersen, must bear a heavy share of responsibility for the disastrous state of the Queensland economy.

SPEECH.PARA: In the final part of my question I asked the Prime Minister whether he saw any relationship between the situation in Queensland and the present industrial turmoil that has been manipulated, manufactured, brought about, by the actions of the Queensland Premier and by his failure to show any measure of preparedness to conciliate and come to agreement with the unions in Queensland that were affected in the initial industrial stoppage in the electricity industry. I asked the Prime Minister whether he could say that in any way the situation in Queensland could have a carryover effect on our national economic situation. As I said a few moments ago, because of the shortness of time, the Prime Minister was not able to go into any detail.

I propose to touch briefly on that situation this evening. I believe that the recent actions of the Queensland Premier have been deliberately directed to allowing the economy of Queensland to reach a ruinous state in the hope that there will be a flow-over effect to the national economy and that this will be to the detriment of this Government. Mr Speaker, this is an absolute fact. What is happening in Queensland today has been deliberately planned by the Premier of Queensland and his Government in an endeavour to manipulate a flow-over effect from the disastrous Queensland economy to the national economy. Let me tell the Queensland Premier that he is going to miss out. He is wide of the mark because the Prime Minister and this Government have the ability to ensure that the effect that he deliberately believes will flow over to the national economy will not result in a downturn of the Australian economy. So he is going to have to find some other way of sorting out his problem in terms of the disgraceful economic situation in Queensland today.

I also want to take one or two moments to show that the mind of this man has become quite senile in recent times. There is no doubt about that. Those who observe and listen to him are well aware of this senility. He has even reached the stage of abusing such people as the Archbishop of Canterbury, who is paying a courtesy visit to Queensland for some days. The Premier, who professes to be a great Christian, is in fact one of the greatest hypocrites that we have seen in this nation. The Archbishop of Canterbury made some very balanced remarks about the industrial situation in Queensland. All he suggested was that these problems can be resolved only by a measure of conciliation by the parties that are involved in the problem, but the Premier told the Archbishop to get out of Australia and go home.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 25 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have a number of meat processing companies in Australia failed to pay slaughter levies by the due date; if so:
(a) what is the name of each company,
(b) what is the period of default,
(c) what amount is owed to the Government, and
(d) what action is the Government taking to recover levies still in arrears.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government collects levies on the slaughter of livestock at abattoirs and meatworks under:
the Livestock Slaughter Levy Act 1964, and
the Pig Slaughter Levy Act 1971

A number of abattoirs and meatworks have failed to pay levies by the due date. In this respect I would remind the honourable member of the difficult economic climate within which operators in the industry are working.

(a) In these circumstances I am sure you will appreciate my reluctance to name individual companies, particularly given the precarious financial situation of many operators and the adverse commercial effect that this would have on them.

At the date of the honourable member's question (25 February 1985) there were seventy two (72) operators that for various reasons had failed to pay levy by the due date. Of these twenty five (25) had ceased operation and were in liquidation or receivership.
(b) The periods of default range from less than a month up to 8 years for companies in liquidation and receivership. The tables below provide an analysis of the situation.
(c) The amount owed by the 47 current operators in the industry was $781,405. Of that amount:
$204,380 has since been paid, clearing the debt of 14 operators and reducing the indebtedness of another 5 operators
$156,984 is being recovered by time-to-pay arrangements currently in force with 7 operators
$218,741 owed by 14 operators is subject to departmental recovery action
$146,710 owed by 10 operators is subject to recovery action via the Australian Government Solicitor's Office and the formal legal processes
$54,590 owed by 2 operators is in dispute as to liability.

In addition to the above, the 25 companies in liquidation or receivership owe a further $1,416,230 which will be reduced when dividends are declared. This situation is also summarised in Table B below.

(d) The Government considers the matter of arrears of levies with the utmost concern and accordingly, my Department is constantly working at reducing the amount of those arrears. However, any action in this regard must take into consideration the full ramifications of recovery action. Obviously it would be unconscionable to instigate the winding up of a company for a debt which may be recoverable by a time-to-pay arrangement.

The measures which currently operate include legislative provisions to both encourage and coerce the honouring of obligations including the imposition of a 20% penalty on arrears. My Department also employs normal credit control procedures incorporating the use of courteous but firm reminder letters and telephone calls, visits by investigation officers and finally recourse to litigation through the offices of the Australian Government Solicitor.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 25 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Medicare offices are established in the Electoral Division of Fairfax and where are they situated.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to widespread concern on the Sunshine Coast from Caloundra to Tewantin that there are insufficient offices to adequately meet the needs and requirements of the residents of this populous and fast growing region.
(3) Has he declined requests for the establishment of additional offices on the Sunshine Coast.

(4) Has his attention also been drawn to the difficulty of many aged, infirm, and disadvantaged citizens not having reasonable access to an office because of limitation of transport facilities and their cost.

(5) Will he review urgently the siting and number of offices on the Sunshine Coast with the object of providing improved and increased access to a Medicare office for all residents of the Electoral Division of Fairfax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are three Medicare offices in the electorate of Fairfax. These offices are located at Caloundra, Nambour and Kawana Waters.
(2) Some requests for additional offices in Fairfax have been received as have requests for other areas.
(3) In the past, requests have been declined as it was felt that three of the 45 offices in Queensland are located within Fairfax and that the distribution adequately covers the needs of the people.

(4) The Health Insurance Commission has reviewed the location and number of Medicare offices in the Sunshine Coast area and continues to be satisfied that the residents of the area have reasonable access to Medicare services. The level of acceptance of direct billing by doctors in the Sunshine Coast area has been good and the doctors in Maroochydore and Noosa/Tewantin direct bill a high percentage of their patients. Where a doctor does not direct bill, the Commission's ability to provide a pay doctor cheque within five working days of receipt means that the residents of the electorate of Fairfax are able to obtain a cheque payable to the doctor with minimum difficulty.
(5) The Health Insurance Commission continues to monitor levels of service and claiming, and it is not intended at this stage to provide further cash offices in the area.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 26 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: What action has he, his Department or any government agency acting on his behalf, taken to ensure that (a) unfounded rumours and allegations, asserting that Stanley Wong was a victim of a crime committed by a Vietnamese or Chinese Vietnamese are rebutted effectively and (b) that any suggestion of a greater tendency to criminal activity by Australian permanent residents of Asian descent, not supported by available evidence or studies, is rebutted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In response to the honourable member's question of 26 February 1985 I wish to state that:

(a) In terms of immediate and practical assistance, officers of my Department moved very swiftly to assist the NSW Police by providing immigration records through which a man was ultimately detained over the murder of Mr Wong. The NSW Police identified the man as a Malaysian national. This was made known to the press and published. This is the most effective rebuttal possible.

(b) I have this year visited each State and Territory capital to meet ethnic community leaders and in speeches and radio broadcasts have made a point of emphasising the notably low rate of criminal activity among first generation migrants.

My Department has a continuing role in reducing misinformation about migration issues, providing factual background to opinion leaders and in other ways fostering understanding, tolerance and social harmony.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Radio Station 2CR's Use of Confidential Electoral Commission Maps

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 27 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can he advise how ABC radio station 2CR obtained a copy of the proposed electoral boundaries for NSW in advance of their release by the Electoral Commission in Sydney, as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 25 July 1984.
(2) Has an inquiry been conducted into the leaking of these confidential maps; if so, who conducted this inquiry, and what were its conclusions.

(3) If an inquiry was completed, (a) were any employees of the NSW Central Mapping Authority found to be implicated and (b) was any action against any Central Mapping Authority employees recommended, if so, what was the recommendation.
(4) If any action was recommended by such an inquiry, was the recommendation implemented; if not, why not.
(5) If no inquiry has been conducted into the leaking of these confidential maps, why not.
(6) What action has he taken to ensure that a similar breach of security will not occur in the future.
(7) Did he discuss the leaking of this map and the implications of the proposed boundaries with any other member of the Government; if so, when.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2), (3) and (4) The Electoral Commissioner has advised that prior to notification of the proposed redistribution of New South Wales, a number of press and electronic media reports predicted with considerable accuracy some of the new boundaries which were subsequently made public. Since at least one press article mentioned an ''authoritative report emanating from the Central Mapping Authority'', the Director of that agency was asked to investigate the matter. In addition the Australian Electoral Officer for New South Wales, who was also a member of the Redistribution Committee for that State, made inquiries among the Divisional Returning Officers in the sixteen rural divisions in the State. None of those enquiries shed further light on the matter which was then referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions for advice. The advice essentially was that no more need be done unless more detailed allegations were made which might give rise to particular avenues of inquiry.
(5) See above.

(6) The Electoral Commissioner has advised that all possible precautions were taken to prevent unauthorised access to information prior to the official release of the proposed maps. However, given the number of persons who have to play a necessary part between the final decisions of the Redistribution Committee being made and the publication of the maps and the Committee's statement of reasons, it would be difficult to prevent unauthorised disclosure by a person should he or she be determined to do so.
(7) I do not recall having the details drawn to my attention, or discussing the matter with anyone.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beddall Mr D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 19 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that there have been cutbacks in the availability of prescribed drugs to aged pensioners; if so, are the cutbacks part of Government policy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme aims to have a comprehensive range of drugs and medicinal preparations available on a subsidised basis to all persons being treated by a medical practitioner in Australia.

There is an ongoing process of review of the drugs available as benefits. Drugs are added to or removed from the Pharmaceutical Benefits list following recommendations made on therapeutic grounds by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC). The PBAC is the statutory committee established under the National Health Act to provide me as Minister for Health with advice on the drugs and medicinal preparations that are to be made available as pharmaceutical benefits.
Drugs may also be removed from the Pharmaceutical Benefits list if discontinued by their manufacturer and no longer available on the market.

There are no pharmaceutical benefits specifically listed for the treatment of pensioners. Routine amendments to the Pharmaceutical Benefits list affect all categories of persons, including pensioners.
The Government is not pursuing a policy of cutback in the availability of prescribed drugs either to pensioners or to other persons.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Residual Constitutional Links with United Kingdom Parliament

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 19 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Government made a decision on the abolition of (a) the Imperial Honours system in Australia and the right of a State to recommend persons for those honours, (b) appeals to the Privy Council from the State courts and (c) the right of State Governments to advise the Queen directly upon the appointment of State Governors, by the Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Discussions are continuing with State Governments and appropriate authorities in the United Kingdom on the severing of residual constitutional links with the United Kingdom Parliament, government and judicial system, including appeals to the Privy Council. The role of the Queen as Queen of Australia is not being in any way weakened. There are no proposals for removing the capacity of any State Government to make recommendations for imperial honours if it wishes. The appropriate channel of advice in relation to the appointment of State Governors (a matter for which State Governments currently do not have the right to advise the Queen directly, as the honourable member's question implies) is one matter being discussed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 19 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that (a) farmers who have decreased their work on the farm to an extent to free them for full-time work are not considered 'unemployed', (b) farmers' wives who normally assist their husbands in farm work when they are freed to be available for full-time work elsewhere, are considered as 'unemployed' and (c) the children of farming families who normally assist their families in farm work, even if they are freed to be available for full-time work elsewhere, are not considered 'unemployed' within the terms of the Social Security Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) To qualify for unemployment benefit, an applicant must be unemployed, capable of undertaking and willing to undertake suitable paid work and be taking reasonable steps to obtain such work. Each application for benefit is considered on its individual merits but the above requirements of the Social Security Act mean that it is unlikely that farmers who are committed to maintaining their farms as ongoing enterprises will satisfy these criteria. The Federal Court has indicated that in considering whether a person may properly be regarded as unemployed, it is necessary to have regard to the person's commitment to their current activities. In the case of a self-employed primary producer this involves an examination of whether there is a commitment to continue farming or to obtain alternative work. Consistent with this view of continuing commitment, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has found that farmers cannot be regarded as unemployed merely because they have arranged their continuing farming activities in such a way as to be available during the normal working week for full-time, off-farm employment.
(b) The wife of a farmer who normally assists her husband in farm work who claims unemployment benefit must satisfy the same eligibility criteria to establish entitlement.
(c) Similarly, children of farming families who normally assist in farm work must satisfy those same criteria.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 21 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the form and style of citizenship certificates issued to those awarded Australian citizenship been changed; if so, why were the certificates changed.
(2) Was one of the reasons for the change the cost of production of the certificates formerly issued.

(3) Has his attention been drawn to (a) the concern and complaints, particularly amongst local municipal officers who present certificates, about the lower standard of quality of the certificates now awarded and (b) the concern amongst individuals who have received the new certificates and who have asked Council officers whether they could change their certificate for one of the former type.
(4) Is consideration being given to re-introducing citizenship certificates, of the standard and quality of those previously issued; if not, why not.
(5) If cost is the factor, what amount is involved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The main reasons for the changes to the certificate were:

(a) to make it compatible with an automated system introduced to streamline the processing of citizenship applications, including the printing of certificates and associated letters, and to contain costs following substantial increases in the application rate over recent years.
(b) to comply with recommendations of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking that certificates of Australian citizenship be made more secure.
(c) to ease the workload of local Government authorities.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.
(4) No. I consider the new certificate to be of acceptable quality. It is secure, versatile and attractive and befits the Australian citizenship status it signifies.

(5) To continue the older style citizenship certificates would have required the purchase of another printer at considerable additional cost, or the employment of up to 20 additional staff to prepare the certificates manually.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 21 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: With respect to the detention of prohibited immigrants, what progress has been achieved in examining the feasibility of developing a separate department custodial service to integrate custodial and administrative responsibilities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Since October 1984 the custodial function at the Immigration Detention Centres has been undertaken by officers of the Australian Protective Service which is within the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services. The custodial staff operate in accordance with guidelines and instructions prepared by my Department in consultation with the Australian Protective Service.
Each detention centre has a manager provided by my Department to attend to all of the local administrative matters and to sort out day-to-day problems as they occur.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: Control of Prohibited Immigration

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 21 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Auditor-General in his efficiency audit on the control of prohibited immigration note as a shortcoming in passenger clearance at airports, that at Sydney Airport departmental officers lacked control over the collection of passenger cards and were therefore unable to ensure that all cards collected from passengers by customs officers were despatched for ADP processing in Canberra.
(2) Did his Department suggest to the Australian Customs Service that from 1 September 1983, clearly defined procedures for checking, access to and despatch of passenger cards should apply.
(3) Following this suggestion did the Auditor-General state that the question of control over passenger cards had not been resolved.
(4) Has this question now been resolved in such a way as to ensure that all cards are collected and despatched for processing.

(5) Did the Auditor-General also state that, while his Department had been installing forgery detection equipment at major airports since 1981, it had yet to confirm that this approach to forgery detection is efficient and cost-effective.
(6) Has his Department now been able to confirm the efficiency of such equipment by way of field trial, if so, what was the result of the trial.

(7) Is he now satisfied that his Department's forgery detection equipment is an effective means of examining documents at airports to detect forgeries, and has his Department now sufficient staff appropriately equipped for routine document examination.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.
(4) The matter has not been resolved; discussions with the Australian Customs Service are continuing.
(5) Yes.

(6) My Department equipped each of the major international airports in Australia with one item of forgery detection equipment which it had developed in conjunction with an Australian firm. The equipment was intended to assist Immigration Inspectors at airports, to have a first ''layman's'' view of the documents and, if more technical examination by an expert was necessary, then to refer the documents for forensic examination. Following successful trials of the prototype, the production model was provided to the airports for immediate operational use from the outset.

Since that initiative, the Department has been successful in its campaign to recruit trained Document Examiners and additionally, some equipment suitable for their use has been developed commercially overseas and is in operational use. Since the audit the Department has therefore been able to move further towards its goal of a system of routine examination of documents at airports based on improved training for Customs Officers in the detection of fraudulent documents, wider provision of relatively inexpensive equipment for Customs Officer use with supporting technical services provided by trained Document Examiners.

(7) I am informed that the Department's forgery detection equipment program is based on equipment assessed by leading technical experts in this field within the immigration services of several countries. Within the limits of the money and the staff that can be made available for this particular area of my Department's activity, I am satisfied that the Department has upgraded its activity, technology and expertise as an appropriate response to the growing concern about the use of fraudulent travel documents. Whether anything more or less needs to be done can only be decided, in due course, on the basis of results and these are being monitored closely.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: Control of Prohibited Immigration

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 21 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Auditor-General in his efficiency audit on the control of prohibited immigration recommend that his Department, while adequately recognising privacy considerations, actively explore with other government authorities the development of procedures to assist in the location of prohibited immigrants, and that other Commonwealth authorities assist to the extent possible in locating people who are in Australia illegally; if so, what action has his Department taken on this recommendation, and what have been the results of its discussions.
(2) Has his Department received adequate co-operation and assistance from other Commonwealth departments and authorities in implementing this recommendation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Yes. My Department advises that it has approached Commonwealth and State authorities over a number of years to provide information which would assist in locating people who are illegally in Australia. While there have been useful results in the past, it has encountered increasing reluctance to provide information because of privacy provisions and aspects of administrative law such as freedom of information legislation. Nevertheless the Department has renewed a number of contacts in writing and in senior officers discussions. I am informed that the responses are mixed, most authorities wanting to be helpful but feeling limited by legislation or policies. When the round of officer level contacts has been completed I will consider whether there is any further action I should take.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: Control of Prohibited Immigration

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 21 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Auditor-General in his efficiency audit on the control of prohibited immigration advocate the use of a less costly reporting system for prohibited immigrants.
(2) Was his Department unable to provide statistics on the use of the reporting system, outlined in his Department's residential control manual, or its failure rate.
(3) Does his Department now collect such statistics on the use of the reporting system and its success or otherwise.
(4) What has resulted from this information being collected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Auditor-General's report states, inter alia, at page 49 that ''Audit explored the potential for greater use of the much less costly 'reporting' system''.

(2) Yes. While information on persons put on reporting arrangements is held in regional offices of my Department, it was not in a form conducive to the ready extraction of the statistics sought by the audit team.
(3) Statistics about people in custody and those not placed in custody and some form of ''Reporting Register'' have been maintained in each region for many years.
These provide the basis for surveys from time to time. My Department considers this adequate rather than an elaborate on-going system of daily statistical reporting.

(4) In mid 1984, following the Auditor-General's views, more extensive use was made of the reporting system as an alternative to custody in a detention centre. This experiment and survey of results revealed that more than half of the illegal immigrants put on report absconded. As a result of the analysis of the information obtained at the time instructions were issued to guide officers in deciding whether a person should be detained. Further surveys will be conducted from time to time on the information subsequently being recorded.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: Control of Prohibited Immigration

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 21 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Auditor-General in his efficiency audit on the control of prohibited immigration report that (a) a computer-generated movements data base of overstayed visitors compiled since 1973 has not provided an accurate and up to date record of overstayed visitors and (b) there was a backlog of approximately 250,000 unmatched movements in the data base.
(2) Did his Department outline additional steps to reduce the backlog of unmatched movements, if so, has each of these steps outlined in the report been put in place.
(3) What is the present backlog of unmatched movements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) and (b) Yes.
(2) Yes; but the steps have been implemented to the following extent:
additional staff have been engaged in this work since August 1983;
planning for the on-line input of extensions of stay and change of immigration status has been continuing but the systems are not yet fully operational;
the ''pre-movement'' data system is being implemented progressively at overseas posts as part of a large, complex and long-term program.

(3) The so-called backlog of unmatched movements is not a once only backlog. As the matching of records of passenger data requires computerised checks of names, date of birth, nationality and other travel details, when there is not an exact match recognisable to the computer, manual checking is necessary. This is a continuous daily activity. From an input of approximately 5 million records per year, about 50,000 mismatches per year require manual checking. As at 28/2/85, 26,298 unmatched records were awaiting final manual checks.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: Audit

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 21 March 1985:

(6) Did the Auditor-General recommend that this development and consequential implementation be completed promptly.
(7) Has the project been completed; if not, why not and when may it be expected that it will be in place.

(8) Did the Auditor-General recommend that a control deficiency existed in the MAL warning system in that there was no reconciliation in relation to additions or deletions from the warning list and those which had been requested.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (6) Yes.
(7) Yes, it has been completed.
(8) and (9) Yes.
(10) Yes, a procedure is in place.

(15) The Department does not single out particular areas which it identifies as 'high-risk' requiring special attention. Standard procedures as outlined in departmental instructions apply to all posts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 21 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What arrangements does the Minister's Department make for the production of films and videos for both internal and external use.
(2) Is any production carried out within the Minister's Department.
(3) How many films/videos were produced for or by the Minister's Department during 1983-84 and what was (a) the title and (b) the cost of each production.

Production is arranged in consultation with Film Australia, and may involve a private film company being employed under contract.

''Medicare'' up-date segment for use with the ''Information About Australia'' counselling video. Cost $30,000.
Multilingual editions of ''Pregnancy and Birth'', a video produced previously in English only. Cost $24,000.
(4) The department holds the following film/video production equipment:
1 x 16mm movie camera-disposal action under way;
1 x film editing table-held in Central Office and used occasionally to preview 16mm films;
1 x Sony U-Matic Portapack system-held in the Melbourne Office and used for training activities;
1 x Sony U-Matic Portapack system-held in Central Office and used for training and other in-house activities;
1 x Sony Video Editing console-held in Central Office and used for training and other in-house activities;
4 x Sony U-Matic Player/Recorders with two monitors-held in Melbourne and Central Offices and used for screening, training and editing purposes.

(5) No one position in the Department is specifically dedicated to film/video production activities. Various officers in the Information Section are involved in aspects of film/video production from time to time, mainly in respect of script-writing and liaison with production organisations. Elsewhere in the Department, two training officers have received some instruction in video production techniques, and a portion of their workload involves producing in-house training videos. Their salaries are $26,330-27,806 and $31,531-35,255.

(2) What is the analysis of these claims giving details of sex, type of duties performed and the number of claims accepted, rejected and finalised.
(3) How many employees are considered to have been successfully rehabilitated, and what steps were taken to achieve rehabilitation.
(4) What steps are being taken to prevent this type of injury.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Details of sex are 47 female, 1 male. Types of duty performed-43 Keyboard, 5 Clerical. Number of claims accepted 33. Number of claims rejected 1. Number of claims finalised 34.
(3) 8 employees are considered to have been successfully rehabilitated.
Steps in rehabilitation included:
Sick leave while undergoing treatment.
Counselling on preventive measures against possible recurrence of RSI.
Replacement of furniture, where advisable, with ergonomically designed work stations.
Temporary re-deployment to other duties, if medically recommended.
(4) Steps being taken to prevent this type of injury include:
Development of departmental policies on the prevention of RSI and the management of RSI cases, including introduction of rest breaks and the designation of an RSI Liaison Officer to counsel staff.

Hiring of professional physiotherapist/ergonomist to give advice and run training courses for keyboard staff and to raise, among supervisors, the level of awareness of RSI and its causes. The courses are designed to help staff identify the initial symptoms of RSI, and emphasise the importance of taking regular rest breaks and of proper posture for keyboard operators.
The provision of ergonomic furniture and other equipment aides.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 26 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government approved the presence of students from Vietnam in Australian universities and colleges.
(2) Under what programs are these students studying in Australia, how many students are involved in each program and how long will each student be in Australia.
(3) Will there be any further students accepted under these programs.

(4) Who selects the students for enrolment in Australia, the Government of Vietnam, the United Nations or some other body or agency and does the Australian Government have any say in the students admitted.

(5) Are fees paid to the Australian institutions at which the students are enrolled; if so, are they paid by the Government of Vietnam, the United Nations, Australia under one of its aid programs, or by some other agency.
(6) What are the fees and are they charged on the basis of the overseas students charge or full cost recovery.
(7) What is the full cost to the institutions for each course of study undertaken by these students.

(8) Have additional arrangements or costs been incurred by Australia for bringing these students to Australia or for undertaking any special measures associated with their presence, including the costs of any special security arrangements; if so, what are the details.

(9) Are these students billeted in university or college student accommodation, if so, are charges levied for this accommodation and are the charges paid for by the sponsoring body or by the Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) At present there are 24 students from Vietnam in Australian universities and colleges. All are studying courses of up to one year under awards administered by the United Nations Development Program (UNDP) (22 students) and the World Health Organisation (WHO) (2 students).
(3) Yes.

(4) Students nominated by the Government of Vietnam undergo final selection by the administering agencies (UNDP and WHO) and the institutions in Australia. They are also subject to Australian Government visa requirements.

(5) and (6) WHO paid the institution fees and the overseas student charge for students whom it administers. UNDP has paid the full charge for a special course for students it administers; because this covers all direct costs and management fees, the overseas student charge is not applicable.
(7) The full cost (including indirect costs) to the institutions has not been calculated, but direct costs are covered as closely as possible by the charges made by the institutions.

(8) A grant of $700,000 has been made to UNDP to cover costs of its Indo-China program, including those of the Vietnamese in Australia. No special security measures have been undertaken other than minor and routine arrangements in relation to some students following an assault on them.
(9) The students have been billeted in university and college accommodation charged to the relevant UN administering organisation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 26 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What special arrangements have been made by his Department to handle appeals expected under the assets test.
(2) How many Social Security Appeals Tribunal members are there in each State and what are their qualifications.
(3) Will there be an increase in the number of members to handle appeals under the assets test.
(4) What is the average time between the submission of an appeal, the hearing of the appeal and the handing down of the appeal from the tribunal.
(5) Will priority be given to the hearing of appeals which arise from the assets test and what is expected to be the average time taken by the tribunal in handing down its decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The existing appeals and review system, with some slight procedural modifications mainly involving valuations by the Australian Taxation Office, will accommodate asset test appeals.

Seminars for Social Security Appeals Tribunal (SSAT) members have recently been held in all States and Territories to acquaint them with the assets test. Officers of the Department have been instructed to handle assets test appeals quickly. Guidelines to assist officers to correctly and quickly handle assets test appeals have already been issued.
(2) Qualifications of SSAT members:
NSW Vic. Qld SA WA Tas. NT ACT
Legal qualifications 14 7 4 2 4 1 1 1 Welfare qualifications or experience 10 9 4 1 5 1 1 1 Medical qualifications 5 4 4 2 3 3 1 1 Seconded from Department of Social Security 5 2 2 1 1 1 1 1

(3) At this stage it is not possible to ascertain the rate at which assets test appeals will be lodged. There have been just over 400 requests made for review. The situation is being constantly monitored and, if the need arises, additional members will be appointed to SSATs to ensure appeals will be dealt with quickly.
(4) Finalisation of non-medical appeals, of which assets test appeals will form part, took an average of 22.7 weeks during the quarter ended December 1984. Over 50% were finalised within 17.7 weeks.

(5) Priority is given to any appeals which involve hardship and this will apply equally to assets test appeals. My department and the SSAT's endeavour to handle all appeals quickly and, as mentioned in answer to question (1), instructions have been issued to ensure assets test appeals do not cause delays in the appeals system generally. It is not possible to assess an expected average time which will be taken by Tribunals in assets test appeals. Tribunals are independent of the Department and their procedures are to a large extent at their discretion. Nevertheless all SSAT members have been informed of the need for speedy resolution of all appeal matters including assets test appeals.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 27 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Australian National Railways Commission considered the provision of side clearance lights to all rolling stock; if so, what was the decision and the reasons for that decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. The Australian National Railways Commission (AN) has investigated using side clearance lights on freight wagons. AN found this to be impractical owing to the difficulty of providing a suitable power source and the necessity to uncouple trains into single wagons and re-marshall.

As the freight wagons of the rail systems are intermingled in operations, any decision to fit side clearance lights would need to be made by the Railways of Australia (RoA) Committee, on which all State railway systems and AN are represented.

I am advised that RoA's attitude to this matter has been not to illuminate wagons due to practical and legal problems inherent in such a proposal. Nevertheless, AN has indicated that it intends to reopen the issue within RoA in an endeavour to achieve some change. AN considers its new corporate livery of green with vertical yellow bands and black contrasts should make its rollingstock considerably more visible at night.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program: Fuel Levies

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 28 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program fuel levy money paid into a trust account which attracts interest.
(2) Is this interest required to be used for road construction and maintenance purposes.
(3) How much interest has accrued since the scheme began, and how much has been paid out for roads.
(4) Is there a regular payment procedure; if so, what is it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Fuel levies paid into the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund (referred to as the Road Fund) which are not immediately required to meet payments to the States and the Northern Territory are invested. Interest earned from such investments is payable into the Road Fund.

(2) Interest received from investments forms part of amounts standing to the credit of the Road Fund from which payments are made by way of financial assistance for the construction of approved projects. Road maintenance is not eligible for assistance.

(3) Total Road Fund interest received to 31 March 1985 was $26,531,248-86. As indicated in response to part (2) payments are made from available credit balances of the Road Fund which include interest received. Total Road Fund payments to 31 March 1985 were $806,687,277.

(4) Yes. Road Fund payments are generally by way of reimbursement of monthly expenditure in each road category. Provision exists for advance payments of approximately a month's estimated expenditure for each road category. Advances are adjusted in line with the value of work completed against approved projects in progress.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) last night spoke in the adjournment debate and suggested that I was being far too emotional about the assets test. If I was emotional, it was with very good reason. That very good reason is that I care about the vast procession of people coming before me and most other members of this House. We on this side of the House care about those people. That is why I make no apology for becoming emotional about something that I believe is absolutely vital. As far as I can see the assets test is being choked up with a vast number of pensioners who are losing their pensions or having their pension reduced by the valuations of the Australian Taxation Office. Many of the valuations are just totally unrealistic. In many cases, if not most cases, the house and curtilage valuations are reduced by at least 50 per cent and the value of the remaining land is inflated. It appears this is done so that the pensioners will be persecuted and lose part or all of their pension.
